story:
Who we are...

After 13 years of friendship, and fulfilling careers in the entertainment industry, Dion and Dannie have set out on a mission to save and empower the youth of Compton - changing the face of a community and making an impact in the lives of others, using their love and passion for the arts. 


Discover.YOU™ is a youth social justice program focused on providing the youth of Compton an avenue to connect to what's possible! By exposing youth to Performing Arts classes (encompassing all genres of dance, acting, choir, musical theatre, creative writing, music production and engineering), providing a global perspective on life through our mentorship program, and encouraging excellency in the Liberal Arts through our tutoring program, our future leaders will be set on the path to success and leadership; furthermore, creating powerful change in their community and around the world. 

Free community workshops (such as Basic Finance, College Prep, Interview Training, Resume Building, Healthy Living, Men's Leadership, and Women Empowerment) will guide students and their families toward financial literacy, liberal arts proficiency, healthy living, higher education and entrepreneurship, and self-empowerment! 

Once a month for the past year and a half, we've held our Compton Dance Free Day. An event for youth in the community to enjoy a day of free dance classes taught by working professionals in the entertainment industry. 


Your help makes a difference…


This brand new facility will be the home of Discover.YOU. Students will feel the love and the passion that we feel for them as they enter a home that was made... JUST FOR THEM!

Here we will build brand new performing arts/dance studios, a recording studio where they will train in music engineering and production, and will have a computer/career center for their tutoring and mentoring. 

Located in Compton, on Rosecrans and Central, this center will be readily available and accessible for students and families in the Compton community - providing a safe haven and offering tools that will guide them toward:
  • Financial Literacy 
  • Liberal Arts Proficiency 
  • Healthy Living 
  • Career Building 
  • Self-Empowerment


Why we must achieve our goal…

As per-student funding continues to decrease in public schools and the number of arts programs being cut increases, the need for students to be guided, motivated, and encouraged to strive for excellency is more imperative than ever. 

We are empowering, inspiring, and training future CEO’s, business men and women, entrepreneurs, scientists, artists, engineers, law makers, and humanitarians. And this is where we will make it happen!!


    Our ways of saying thank you...

    Our goal is to raise $500,000 to secure the building that will house our programming!! Your donation not only makes this possible, but also ensures that our program will run for one full year!! Here are a few ways we want to share our appreciation for your contribution:




      A few numbers in Compton, CA…


      We must be the change…

      Currently, the Compton Unified School District has a graduation rate of only 47%; far below that of the overall California graduation rate of 71.2%. 

       Discover.YOU™ fully recognizes the dire need of mentorship and guidance for our youth, and commit to addressing it head on via our workshops for men, women empowerment seminars, leadership events, and one on one mentoring for students.


      Our Core Values…

      LOVE:: Providing the community a safe haven filled with mentors, artists, and educators who operate solely out of love to inspire our youth, introduce them to a world with endless opportunities, and passionately guide them towards their dreams. We will be love personified.
      INTEGRITY:: Helping our youth lay the foundation for their lives; entering into the world with an undeniable focus, maintaining their high standards, understanding and heeding to their moral values, and unable to be easily beset. Their integrity will transcend into their leadership.
      FAITH:: Instilling an unshakeable faith whereby our youth will create positive change in their lives, solidify a powerful future that impacts the lives of others, and leave with a better understanding of who they are, where they are going in life, and more importantly how to get there.
      EDUCATION:: By offering Performing Arts classes, youth are introduced to a cultural worldview and a broader perspective on what impact they want to leave in the world. Through financial workshops/resume building (for youth and parents), tutor sessions, and mentoring, we educate them on life skills, vigorously prepare them for higher education and entrepreneurship, promote the reduction of the high school dropout and prostitution rates, and guide them through their pursuit of an empowered life.



        Other Ways You Can Help...

story:
What is "Different Together"?

The idea behind Different Together (Embracing Our Differences Israel) is simple. Everyone has the right to feel safe, to be empowered and to make a positive difference to their community.  Our goal is to encourage respect for diversity and inclusion , and to promote the significance of the active rejection of hatred and prejudice in Israel and throughout the world.

The centerpiece of Different Together will be an outdoor art exhibit in Jaffa featuring billboard size images created by Israeli students of all religions and races. 

The Jewish Federation of Sarasota-Manatee County in Florida is partnering with The Daniel Centers in Israel to bring the “Different Together” exhibit to the historic Port of Jaffa from March 19-April 19th. Different Together is winning artwork from students throughout Israel who want to represent the rich diversity of Israel. Your support will bring this display to life for everyone to celebrate. In a time of challenges, we urge you to be a part of an all-inclusive, positive experience that celebrates being Different Together in Israel!

What We Need & What You Get

Your generosity celebrates Israel’s diversity with the ”Different Together” Exhibit in Israel:

  • $2,000 will purchase a panel of exhibit artwork with you listed as sponsor at the Port of Jaffa

  • $1,000 will purchase a panel of exhibit artwork with you listed as co-sponsor at the Port of Jaffa

  • $500 will sponsor a quotation included in the exhibit artwork at the Port of Jaffa

  • $36-$499 will be a Friend of "Different Together" and get your name listed on a banner at the exhibit at the Post of Jaffa

  • $1-$35 will show your support of "Different Together" and you'll receive a tagged "thank you" post on Facebook

The Impact & Our Partners

 Participating local partners: Embracing Our Differences& Sarasota Sister Cities 

Participating overseas partners: The Daniel Center for Progressive Judaism, Tel Mond, Israel & Israel Tennis Centers

Participating Israeli Schools: Usishkin (Elementary); Golomb (Elementary); Bavli (Elementary); HaMishtala (Elementary); Bialik-Rogozin (Elementary through High school)

Participating Israeli institutions: The Tel Aviv Community Center Association; The Tel Mond Community Center; The MPJ Mechina at Jaffa; "A New Way" - Jewish-Arab Initiative

Inspired by Embracing Our Differences in Sarasota, Florida (www.embracingourdifferences.org), we're taking this initiative internationally to Israel. In a country the size of the state of New Jersey, Israel is home to over 30 spoken languages, a myriad of cultures, several religions, and diverse lifestyles. More than ever, all the people of Israel need international support in order to be "Different Together." With your support, this art exhibit can be a catalyst for discussion, acceptance of differences, and ultimately peace.

Risks & Challenges

The Jewish Federation of Sarasota-Manatee in partnership with the Daniel Centers for Progressive Judaism in Israel are committed to bringing the "Different Together" exhibit to the historic Port of Jaffa. This project requires skilled and trusted workers to install the structures necessary to host the artwork. Your generosity will ensure that the right workers are hired to correctly and safely complete the installation. 

Safety is always a concern. We aim to present the "Different Together" exhibit as a beacon of joy and hope. However, public safety is a growing concern for all people in Israel and must be taken into consideration when visiting the Port of Jaffa.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!

  • Write a short personal message to friends and ask them to donate at:  http://igg.me/at/DifferentTogether
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools in all your social media outlets!

story:
About the Project

I created Construction Zone in a fit of frustration as I tried to navigate dance school as a nonbinary person. Why did everyone assume I was "in between" two genders? Why couldn't my teachers get my name right? Why did people assume I was a girl even when I constantly informed them I wasn't? Why was it so much more exciting for my classmates and teachers to see a man on pointe than to see me doing my work? What was the draw of gender bending that made me invisible?

As I realized that my school wasn't going to help me, I reached out to members of my queer/trans communities for help on the project. I had deep discussions about gender and art and lots of help chaining yellow yarn as the project wore on. It wasn't just a chance to make art, I was able to build deeper ties with my community.

I presented the work in a glass room in the center of my school, visible to all. It was an act of defiance and claiming space, not just for me, but for the community that had supported me, and for all nonbinary performers navigating the complexities of cis-dominated spaces. To this day, I still consider it one of my biggest successes. 

Now, for the first time, I have the opportunity to present Construction Zone to the public on June 15th at Make Shift Boston! Make Shift itself regularly supports nonbinary artists and I am so excited to take this opportunity to expand conversations about nonbinary performance beyond the confines of a single dance school in a space which is already doing this work. 

Nonbinary dancers live in a lonely world and this is my (OUR) chance to take space, build community, and ask all folks with binary genders to engage with the question of nonbinary performance on nonbinary terms. 

This project was born of anger and frustration, but it has become so much more. Please come and join our community!

Where is your money going?

Bare minimum cost of the project: $1,470

I am so grateful to the New England Foundation for the Arts for a grant of $730. 

I still need to raise $740 in order to run the installation. I am expecting to get some donations at the door, but will not be able to open that door to run the installation without prior support. 

Breakdown: 

Artist/administrative/consulting fees: $279

Space for rehearsal/preparation: $200

Space for the installation to run for 4 hours, including set-up and takedown: $250

Materials (Yarn, paper, markers, clothespins): $404

Documentation (Quality photography from a nonbinary photographer to help give the project life, so it can be expanded and repeated!): $300

Fundraising fees (5% of donations): $37

-

Over 50% of this money goes towards supporting nonbinary artists!

Money going directly going into the pockets of nonbinary artists: $579 (39% of budget)

Money going to organizations that support nonbinary artists: $450  (31% of budget)

 

Why does this matter?

 

Trans in dance: The frustrations I had at my dance school came from the fact that the greater dance community is incredibly transphobic and unwelcoming. Even in inclusive dance spaces, I feel unwelcome and am usually stuck in the uncomfortable position of being the only trans person in the room, an accidental token. I know I am not the only one hurting. In supporting this project, you are giving trans people a chance to make work on our terms, not just for me, but for all the connections that come from incredible, audible trans art.  

Nonbinary performance: So much of nonbinary performance has been reduced to a binary perspective - someone the audience should perceive as a man with feminine traits, someone the audience should perceive as FAAB (female-assigned at birth) dressed in a nice suit jacket. And SO MUCH of this is done by and for the benfit cis people at the expense of the rich depth and breadth of nonbinary identities. As I develop this project, I will be consulting with other nonbinary performers so it can expand to represent multiple nonbinary identities, not just mine. 

In supporting this project, you are giving nonbinary performers a platform to really show you who we are and what we can be. 

Supporting Queer Art: Artists, in general, are underfunded. Queer artists are severely underfunded. As a nonbinary performer, I work multiple jobs with no benefits (no sick days. no vacation. no health insurance) and, again, I know I am not the only one struggling. I am only hiring nonbinary artists, consultants, assistants, and photographers to be part of this project and the space I am renting regularly hires and supports nonbinary artists. In supporting this project, you are not just helping me make art, you are putting money directly towards nurturing and supporting nonbinary artists.

Access to art: Art costs money, which makes it inaccessible. The work I do is by and for a community that is already struggling financially, so it is deeply important to me to increase access to art by making the event free to all. Even at donation-only events, it's common for there to be pressure to donate a set amount, which can be alienating to folks who can't afford it. With your support, I can keep donations an opt-in only for people who can afford it and you will be making the art world a little more accessible to all. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge is that I'm young and inexperienced. I've never done anything like this before! But that's also exciting. It's become a chance to talk to more experienced people about producing an event like this, fundraising, and just Making a Thing Happen. I'm learning so much! And, it also means the project's success could have a huge positive impact on my career. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not able to support Construction Zone with money, but still want to help? That's awesome! In my community, everyone is welcome! Here are some things you can do:

- Share the project on social media and with your friends and family! (Tip: I've got a facebook page with easy, shareable posts)

- Mark your calendar for June 15th so you can participate in the installation! More details coming soon!

- What is gender to you? Help build the construction virtually.
story_txt:
About the Project
I created Construction Zone in a fit of frustration as I tried to navigate dance school as a nonbinary person. Why did everyone assume I was "in between" two genders? Why couldn't my teachers get my name right? Why did people assume I was a girl even when I constantly informed them I wasn't? Why was it so much more exciting for my classmates and teachers to see a man on pointe than to see me doing my work? What was the draw of gender bending that made me invisible?
As I realized that my school wasn't going to help me, I reached out to members of my queer/trans communities for help on the project. I had deep discussions about gender and art and lots of help chaining yellow yarn as the project wore on. It wasn't just a chance to make art, I was able to build deeper ties with my community.
I presented the work in a glass room in the center of my school, visible to all. It was an act of defiance and claiming space, not just for me, but for the community that had supported me, and for all nonbinary performers navigating the complexities of cis-dominated spaces. To this day, I still consider it one of my biggest successes. 
Now, for the first time, I have the opportunity to present Construction Zone to the public on June 15th at Make Shift Boston! Make Shift itself regularly supports nonbinary artists and I am so excited to take this opportunity to expand conversations about nonbinary performance beyond the confines of a single dance school in a space which is already doing this work. 
Nonbinary dancers live in a lonely world and this is my (OUR) chance to take space, build community, and ask all folks with binary genders to engage with the question of nonbinary performance on nonbinary terms. 
This project was born of anger and frustration, but it has become so much more. Please come and join our community!

Where is your money going?
Bare minimum cost of the project: $1,470
I am so grateful to the New England Foundation for the Arts for a grant of $730. 
I still need to raise $740 in order to run the installation. I am expecting to get some donations at the door, but will not be able to open that door to run the installation without prior support. 
Breakdown: 
Artist/administrative/consulting fees: $279
Space for rehearsal/preparation: $200
Space for the installation to run for 4 hours, including set-up and takedown: $250
Materials (Yarn, paper, markers, clothespins): $404
Documentation (Quality photography from a nonbinary photographer to help give the project life, so it can be expanded and repeated!): $300
Fundraising fees (5% of donations): $37
-
Over 50% of this money goes towards supporting nonbinary artists!
Money going directly going into the pockets of nonbinary artists: $579 (39% of budget)
Money going to organizations that support nonbinary artists: $450  (31% of budget)
 

Why does this matter?
 
Trans in dance: The frustrations I had at my dance school came from the fact that the greater dance community is incredibly transphobic and unwelcoming. Even in inclusive dance spaces, I feel unwelcome and am usually stuck in the uncomfortable position of being the only trans person in the room, an accidental token. I know I am not the only one hurting. In supporting this project, you are giving trans people a chance to make work on our terms, not just for me, but for all the connections that come from incredible, audible trans art.  
Nonbinary performance: So much of nonbinary performance has been reduced to a binary perspective - someone the audience should perceive as a man with feminine traits, someone the audience should perceive as FAAB (female-assigned at birth) dressed in a nice suit jacket. And SO MUCH of this is done by and for the benfit cis people at the expense of the rich depth and breadth of nonbinary identities. As I develop this project, I will be consulting with other nonbinary performers so it can expand to represent multiple nonbinary identities, not just mine. 
In supporting this project, you are giving nonbinary performers a platform to really show you who we are and what we can be. 
Supporting Queer Art: Artists, in general, are underfunded. Queer artists are severely underfunded. As a nonbinary performer, I work multiple jobs with no benefits (no sick days. no vacation. no health insurance) and, again, I know I am not the only one struggling. I am only hiring nonbinary artists, consultants, assistants, and photographers to be part of this project and the space I am renting regularly hires and supports nonbinary artists. In supporting this project, you are not just helping me make art, you are putting money directly towards nurturing and supporting nonbinary artists.
Access to art: Art costs money, which makes it inaccessible. The work I do is by and for a community that is already struggling financially, so it is deeply important to me to increase access to art by making the event free to all. Even at donation-only events, it's common for there to be pressure to donate a set amount, which can be alienating to folks who can't afford it. With your support, I can keep donations an opt-in only for people who can afford it and you will be making the art world a little more accessible to all. 
 

Risks & Challenges
The biggest challenge is that I'm young and inexperienced. I've never done anything like this before! But that's also exciting. It's become a chance to talk to more experienced people about producing an event like this, fundraising, and just Making a Thing Happen. I'm learning so much! And, it also means the project's success could have a huge positive impact on my career. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Not able to support Construction Zone with money, but still want to help? That's awesome! In my community, everyone is welcome! Here are some things you can do:
- Share the project on social media and with your friends and family! (Tip: I've got a facebook page with easy, shareable posts)
- Mark your calendar for June 15th so you can participate in the installation! More details coming soon!
- What is gender to you? Help build the construction virtually.

story:
Ustu is a small embroidery clothing brand based in Brooklyn, NY created by Amelia Rami and Harlan Hue. 
As Harlan was finishing up his Fine Art degree in 2017 and Amelia working in the fashion industry, the two began to collaborate on fashion related projects, creating embroidered pants while slowly forming our brand Ustu. 

Just as Ustu began gaining momentum, everything came to a halt. After graduating in 2018, our University would no longer allow us access to their digital embroidery machines, therefore stopping all Ustu production.

We are now looking to advance the brands possibilities with this campaign, we hope to receive enough funds to purchase our own digital embroidery machine. 

These machines are extremely advanced and expensive. The specific Embroidery Machine model we are looking to get is made by Brother sewing company, its called the "DreamMaker XE VE2200" and costs $4,500. 

Receiving funds for this project would allow us to continue creating and producing embroidered items under our brand Ustu. We now share an art studio together and have more ideas than ever. With funds received from this campaign, we would finally be able purchase  the embroidery machine for our studio, where we can give life to the designs we've been curating for the brand over this past year. 

Donating to this project has a variety of perks, a donator could receive a hand drawn thank-you letter, a pair of ustu pants, a custom painting, and much more.

 

If you are unable to provide a donation, please feel free to share/repost our page.

Thanks!

With Love,

Ustu

(Amelia @curleerami, Harlan @harlanhue)

story:
A World Premiere in the Nation's Capital 

Steal A Step is making its first show, and we need your help! Kick Before You Drown will premiere at the Capital Fringe Festival on July 7-14, 2016, at the Atlas Performing Arts Center in Washington DC. The show will explore the lengths people will go to be desired and what they will sacrifice in themselves to find intimacy.

Our goals for the show include the following:

  • Push the bounds of contemporary circus into performance art
  • Expose American audiences to a new art form
  • Challenge the notion that proximity is necessary for creative collaboration

We have our cast, our acts, and our music . . . and now we just need your help to turn on the lights and bring this show to the stage.

Watch our appeal video.

What is Steal A Step? What is contemporary circus?

Steal A Step grew out two movement innovators’ desire to stretch the bounds of American circus and to create ephemeral and authentic experiences for the performer and audience. American circus has been traditionally viewed as clowns, animals, and show girls, but in Europe and Canada contemporary circus is already well established and respected as a mix of circus skill, theater, and dance. It is expected to provoke emotion rather than to focus solely on technical skill.

In trying to apply the lessons of postmodernism to circus, Steal A Step is trying to stretch the bounds of American contemporary circus into performance art through non-linear shows that challenge the rules of settled society and invite the audience to enter the artistic fray. 

  • Founder Joshua Handal holds a bachelor’s degree in contemporary circus performance from the Ecole de Cirque de Quebec, one of the most prestigious circus arts programs in Northern America. While in Canada, he worked with his trapeze partner Marie to create contemporary and abstract movement on duo trapeze through their brand Duo Josh and Marie. Combining dissonant music with abrupt and often spastic changes in movement, the duo set out to challenge preconceptions in the discipline. Josh also has a degree in mechanical engineering and business from The University of Virginia and is an accomplished pianist and composer.
  • Founder Jessica John is a circus artist, coach, and choreographer who specializes in aerial rope, fabric, and dance trapeze. An ardent movement researcher, she was a competitive athlete, a teenage "rockette," and a ski bum, before finding a passion for the circus arts. Jessica challenges gender stereotypes through displays of virtuosic strength and flexibility and creates empathetic space for her characters through rich storytelling and compelling visuals. A sixth generation New Orleanian, Jessica is the creative and managing director of Vaudoux Aerial Dance Theatre. Jessica also has a degree in political science from the University of Colorado, a master’s degree from George Washington University, and a law degree from Boston University.

How Far Will You Go?

Through our crowdfunding campaign, we are attempting to raise $10,000. This is the bare minimum that we need to transport our artists to DC and pay them. Our costs will total over $20,000, however, which we are attempting to raise through fundraising, sponsorships, and ticket sales. Everything that you can donate over $10,000 will diminish the stress on other funding sources and improve the quality of our show.

By donating to this show, you are making art possible. You are contributing to a discipline in flux and exposing new audiences to contemporary circus. Donating to our show at any level will get you endless appreciation and, if you are lucky, scantily clad circus artists spelling out your name in chocolate syrup on their bodies. You folks are rockstars.

Other Ways To Help

If you are a starving artist with no money to spare, we feel you. You can still help us by spreading the word on social media to friends, family, or wealthy patrons about Steal A Step, Kick Before You Drown, and this campaign. You have spare airline miles? You would like to cater our rehearsals? Sponsor our late-night wine binges? Know a guy who can print our programs super cheap? Send all that love our way. And enjoy the show.


This production is presented as a part of the 2016 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington DC non-profit Capital Fringe.


Steal A Step is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Steal A Step must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
About the Scholarship

Cameron Hockenson was an amazing person whose love of art and travel touched many lives. He was a tireless educator, artist, and adventurer, who guided people through historical sites and into unknown not-oft explored parts of the world to fully experience these places through art and art history.

What Happens when you Donate

In leu of giving gifts at his memorial, we ask that you donate to this Scholarship Fund instead. It financially aids students who could not otherwise travel abroad, and lead to life-enriching experiences in Cameron's honor. Cameron believed that the most impactful experiences one could have was to travel with intent. With your donation, we can ensure that students who otherwise are limited from seeing the world have the ability to. In this way, we honor Cameron Hockenson in his passion and legacy.

The first trip your donation will be put towards is allowing students of Mark Van Proyen at the San Francisco Art Institute to go to the Venice Biennale, an art exhibition that Cameron had always wanted to attend and participate in.

See some of Cameron Hockenson's art, most of which was created abroad and at residencies.

story:
Short Summary

Hello.

My name is Star Montana and I am a Photo-based Artist from Boyle Heights California.

I am seeking help to fund my first museum solo exhibition.
Tear Drops and Three Dots.

A long term family series based on the destruction and redemption of my Family based in East Los Angeles.

Chapters: (Click titles to View work)
Saint Louisa Ascends
Saint Louis is our Salvation
will be exhibited together for the first time, showing the chronological timeline of the death of my mother and my family recombining focusing on Louise the baby of our Family as our hope and redemption in our mouring state.

The Impact

Debuting Tear Drops and Three Dots at the Vincent Price Art Museum on the East Los Angeles Campus is my dream debut for this work.

My photography began at East Los Angeles College.

It saved me, it focused me out of Chaos and allowed me to channel my angst into Photography.

I want East Los Angeles to be accessible to my work.

Risks & Challenges

Without the help of my community, the quality of the show will be impacted.

If I cannot fund raise at least half the show cost (500$) by January 5th.
I will have to decline the invitation to do my first solo show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know, I'm asking for help during the Holiday season so If you can't help I totally understand but you can help by Sharing my campaign.

 Thank you for reading and please join me February 20th 2016 at my opening reception.

story:
The story behind "Unknown Rome"

My name is Michele Sanvico, As a writer of novels and essays, I explore worlds that are unseen by most people. The city of Rome makes no exception. Rome is like a treasure chest: if you unlock it with delicate fingers, you'll find the jewels which are hidden behind the Colosseum, the Vatican, Piazza Navona.

And if you possess the right map, you will find a bounty of astonishing places.

That map is just here: A Guide to Unknown Rome.


A wonderful, contemporary Grand Tour

Off the beaten track, the visitor will connect to the web portal of "Unknown Rome" using a smartphone or tablet: the wonders of Rome will be at hand, from ancient underground Rome to the most picturesque baroque corners, from the unusual and attractive museum to the less-known open-air parks and ruins.

The Grand Tour is not over. All sites are still there, forgotten by the day-tourist, ready to let their beauty flow before the traveller's eyes. Just like centuries ago.


Funds will build up the Unknown Rome map

The web design framework is ready. You can connect right now to http://www.italianwriter.it/UnknownRome/Guide_t... and look at the general arrangement of visual and text data. However, some forty places in Rome (Phase 1) must still be loaded as content pages, each linked to the main gateway page. Thirty additional places (Phase 2) will end up the task.

For each place, a detailed, ready-to-use web card is set up, containing the most beautiful images of the site. An English description helps the tourist understand the reasons for visiting the place - a church, a garden, a subterranean site, a palace. Quotes from the Grand Tour travellers of the past will illuminate the site with the light of poetry and literature.

The whole process of creating the cards will take time. Costs will be covered through crowd funding.


The importance of Unknown Rome

There is nothing like that on the web . Hundreds of sites babble about Piazza di Spagna or the Musei Capitolini, but NO WEB SITE provides any complete guidance to the traveller on the hidden, picturesque, less-known place to be found in the celebrated city of Rome.

"A Guide to Unknown Rome" will improve the experience that thousands of tourist have in Rome every day: a discovery, a travel in time, a plunge into art and history. Places which are not known even to today's Roman residents will open their doors to the attentive foreign visitor.


Other Ways You Can Help

Have you ever been in Rome? Did you discover any impressive, magnificent place or corner during your stay? Send a notice on that to michele.sanvico@italianwriter.it. The project might include your suggested site too!

If you have friends who love Italy, Rome and the history of Grand Tour, do not hesitate to tell them about "A Guide to Unknown Rome" project and funding!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Yvette Groover and I am a 25 year old artist in Kansas City, MO. I have been working with clay since middle school but really developed a passion during high school and college in Colorado. I moved to Kansas City with the plan of sharing my work and I am finally doing just that.  

For the last year and a half, I worked at an art studio supporting adults with developmental disabilities to create, showcase and sell their work. I was able to introduce them to throwing on the wheel, hand building, altering thrown pieces and so much more. Through teaching them it stirred up my love for clay even more and they have each inspired me to start sharing my own work.

I have been working daily on transforming my basement from a scary dungeon into a bright and colorful ceramic studio. There has been lots of cleaning, painting, organizing and building but I have got almost everything done! The wedging table is ready, the wheel spins smooth like buttah and all the scary spiderwebs are gone. The only thing to make this studio complete is a  kiln to fire work.

Currently, I am creating pieces at home then driving across town to fire them at local clay guild. While having access to this kiln has made working from my home studio possible, it raises the chances of breaking pieces during transportation before they are fired. The local clay guild also only fires their work to a temperature that would melt almost all of my pieces if I attempted to do my glaze firings there. At this point, I can fire all of my pieces the first time but then they are left naked with no option to glaze fire them.

With a kiln here, I would be able to fire all of my pieces without transportation for the first (bisque) and glaze firing, have control of the temperature (for no melting and more experimentation), fire my class's work without transportation and widen the variety of options I have for surface decorations.

What We Need & What You Get

I never would have thought this campaign would reach its goal on its first day but you guys proved me wrong! Thank you all soooooo much. Since this campaign has passed the goal of funding a kiln I thought it would be nice to let you know how the funds would be used. I am also setting a new goal for $1000! There is definitely still time to make this happen. Currently, thats only $375 away and would mean being able to get all of these things:
  • $500 for a used kiln (check!)
  • Air Purifier $90(check!)
  • Glazes $300
  • Throwing Bats $60
  • Tools $50
  • Since the initial goal has been reached reached ALL funder will receive an extra handmade perk! 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    In case you can't contribute to this there are still other ways for you to help!

    • Check out my etsy shop and see if anything tickles your fancy! www.etsy.com/shop/PiCeramics
    • Find me on Facebook (PiCeramics) or Instragram (@espeayzi) to keep up on whats going in the studio!
    • Share this with your friends and tell them about it! Just don't spam them, k?

There has been lots of cleaning, painting, organizing and building but I have got almost everything done! The wedging table is ready, the wheel spins smooth like buttah and all the scary spiderwebs are gone. The only thing to make this studio complete is a  kiln to fire work.


Currently, I am creating pieces at home then driving across town to fire them at local clay guild. While having access to this kiln has made working from my home studio possible, it raises the chances of breaking pieces during transportation before they are fired. The local clay guild also only fires their work to a temperature that would melt almost all of my pieces if I attempted to do my glaze firings there. At this point, I can fire all of my pieces the first time but then they are left naked with no option to glaze fire them.
With a kiln here, I would be able to fire all of my pieces without transportation for the first (bisque) and glaze firing, have control of the temperature (for no melting and more experimentation), fire my class's work without transportation and widen the variety of options I have for surface decorations.
   What We Need & What You Get
I never would have thought this campaign would reach its goal on its first day but you guys proved me wrong! Thank you all soooooo much. Since this campaign has passed the goal of funding a kiln I thought it would be nice to let you know how the funds would be used. I am also setting a new goal for $1000! There is definitely still time to make this happen. Currently, thats only $375 away and would mean being able to get all of these things: 
$500 for a used kiln (check!)
Air Purifier $90(check!)
Glazes $300
Throwing Bats $60
Tools $50
Since the initial goal has been reached reached ALL funder will receive an extra handmade perk! 

  Other Ways You Can Help In case you can't contribute to this there are still other ways for you to help! 
Check out my etsy shop and see if anything tickles your fancy! www.etsy.com/shop/PiCeramics
 Find me on Facebook (PiCeramics) or Instragram (@espeayzi) to keep up on whats going in the studio!
Share this with your friends and tell them about it! Just don't spam them, k?

story:
Sometimes opportunity is thrust before you by what seems to be completely by chance. 

My name is Jody Fallon.  I am an artist working in oils, watercolor, pastels, acrylic and also sculpture.  My wife is Cheryl Fallon a photographic artist. After 12 years of painting full time and 7 years of shlepping work all over Pennsylvania and into New York City, we have been presented with this amazing opportunity to have our very own physical gallery in Lancaster, PA’s Gallery Row neighborhood.  This opportunity was completely unexpected and as such we are not exactly financially prepared, again we are working artists.  We do not have “day jobs” or pensions or any sort of financial assistance.   We have survived and raised our two small boys solely on the fruit of our work.  So….we are having a fundraiser to raise funds to get the gallery set-up and to open the doors.

Those of you how know me personally know that I am passionate about art and the need to share it with everyone.  I have been hosting my own solo art exhibit annually at the Packwood House Museum in Lewisburg for the last 8 years.  These exhibits have been very successful, but now we are ready to have a permanent physical location where I can present not only our work but also the work of artists that I have admired for years, artists that very few people outside of Central Pa have had the opportunity to view.

You can read the whole story of how this opportunity came out of nowhere HERE.

We need your help to seize this amazing opportunity and take this to the next level.

 

What We Need

Right now, we will need approximately $5,000 to get the gallery off the ground.   I am charging ahead to meet this goal, but like I said, this opportunity came up unexpectedly!

The sole purpose of this fundraiser is to raise funds towards preparing the gallery for exhibiting work and initial promotion and advertising. 

We will be opening the doors on August 3rd.  The gallery is located at 113 North Water Street, Lancaster, PA.  

 COSTS INCLUDE (but are definitely not limited to):

  • Lighting
  • Signage
  • Fresh Paint
  • Advertising
  • Flyers, postcards and mailings
  • Supplies to create and hang new work for the opening
  • Framing
  • Truck rental to deliver the work and furnishings to the space
  • Initial start-up fees 


What You Get

I could never ask this of you without offering something in return besides  awesome, inspring art shows.  So we are offering a number of exclusive and limited edition pieces just for this fundraiser as well as original one of a kind works of art.  All prints and giclees will be hand-sgned and the edition will be limited only to number of you that sign-up for these perks.

Please feel free to give in any increment you like as every penny will help.

The Impact

I've spent the last 12 years of my life creating and selling my original works. Being able to lay down roots in a fabulous space like this will enable me to not only exhibit my own work but share with all of you the amazing talents of a host of other artists. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough, and I understand if you yourself cannot contribute to this fundraiser. However, I do ask that you share this campaign through your own networks, be it Facebook, Twitter, etc. to get the word out! Indigogo itself has a whole host of sharing tools right through this page, please use them! 


Images of Rewards

 

 11x14 Signed Print - "All Gonna Be" by Cheryl Fallon

 

11x14 Signed Print - "Paula's Garden" by Cheryl Fallon

 

"Queen Anne's Lace" an original watercolor by Jody Fallon

For the first time, Jody Fallon will be creating Watercolor Giclée of his original watercolor "Queen Anne's Lace". These prints are available as either 11x14 or 16x20 and ONLY available  through this fundraiser.  They will be hand-signed and numbered, printed on watercolor paper with deckled edges.

story:
If you are looking for a gift for yourself or a friend - what could be better than being able to feature an art work in the Art Prizes Calendar for all of 2013?

 

About our project

Art Prizes and festivals are the life blood of most artist's practices now that so many art galleries are closing. That's why, you want to improve your chances of winning by having much more time to get ready for your favourite art prizes. If you just rely on "Call for Entries" in magazines and newspapers and you miss the ad does that mean you are going to lose out? Not if you are using the Art Prizes website. We give you dates and information about forthcoming prizes well in advance of the "Call for Entries". With our Watchlist and Add-to-Calendar buttons you can keep tabs on all the prizes that interest you and not worry about missing ads in the journals. Click here to see a brief video of how this works on our current site.

And, we are doing all this right now, in Australia! Now we want to help you no matter what country you live in. Two years ago I built Art Prizes Australia from scratch and now it enjoys the patronage of over 6,000 artists and photographers.

But what about the fabulous art prizes available to artists in America, Europe, Asia? Help me raise the funds to produce a website, pdf magazine and each year a printed magazine which will feature the best and most interesting prizes and festivals around the world.

If you are an artist you will be able to see

  • the dates for prizes are being held,
  • where they are being held
  • who to contact and when the prize will call for entries.

This gives you a great shot at getting ready months before you see the "Call for entries" advertised.

Tin tacks

What will the money grow?

It will be used to help me go visit first hand, or at the very least contact art prizes and important festivals so I can do the quality research and let people know all about the Art Prizes site. Then it will go to producing a website and at the same time the first issue of the Prizes and Festivals planner. And from there we will work hard to build a really wonderful resource for artists.

If there are sufficient funds and demand we will also create a world prizes and festivals app for your smart phone. 

With your support the production will go like this:

  1. Building on everything we have learnt about art prizes and festivals we will build a new website and publication for International Prizes and Festivals and build the international art prizes website
  2. Get to work by expanding our listing of international art prizes by contacting or visiting as many as possible as soon as possilble
  3. Then produce an International Art Prizes pdf planner (taking off from our Australian Prizes Planner)
  4. Publish an ebook (pdf) which will feature the best of the international art prizes, including pictures, interviews and information. What a great way to learn about what each prize offers
  5. Finally, if we get over our target there are some really wonderful Stretch Goals.

The Art Prizes Planner (pdf) is a calendar based view of forthcoming prizes over the year. It will list as many of the art prizes as possible at any given time and is regularly updated.

 

The Art Prizes ebook is a one-off look at some of the most popular international art prizes.

Stretch Goals

Over $30,000 -  Our ebook for free featuring international art prizes for anyone who contributed $50 or more.

story:
THE STORY OF "THE NEXT THING" (TNT)

 

The Next Thing: Art in the 21st Century is a collection of illustrated essays written by a broad range of world renowned artists and theorists all attempting to anticipate the aesthetic sensibility that will define our century.

 

Edited by fiction writer and theorist Pablo Baler, the book will come out in September 2012, published by Rowman & Littlefield under the Fairleigh Dickinson University Press imprint.

 

The list of contributors include: Stelarc (Australia), Salima Hashmi (Pakistan), Liliana Porter (Argentina/U.S.), Ana Tiscornia (Uruguay/U.S.), Mieke Bal (Neatherlands), Sue "Johnny" Golding (England), Glenn Harper (U.S.),  Polona Tratnik (Slovenia), Jan Castro (U.S.), Peng Feng (China), Hagi Kenaan (Israel), Mark Axelrod (U.S.)

 

Among those involved in this book, The Next Thing was quickly nicknamed "TNT"... not only a good sounding acronym but also a reflection on our confidence on the explosive nature of this project and its promise as one of the major editorial events of the century.

 

 

 

THE IMPACT

This international anthology examines current artistic manifestations: from "post-human" installations, to transgenic experimentations, from tele-presence performance, to nano-design, virtual urbanism or "guerilla art", to name but a few contemporary tendencies that are redefining both the boundaries of Meaning and what it means to be Human in the 21st century. 


Indeed, The Next Thing will become a unique forum for current critical discussions about contemporary art and will also be a reference point for artists and thinkers of the future. The Next Thing will not only offer a high quality visual gateway into the work of contemporary trailblazing artists but it will also provide an interdisciplinary framework to examine the intellectual and emotional underpinnings of our current revolution in the Arts.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

If you read this far, YOU are the one we are counting on...

Art has always relied on those who not only shared the vision but also were able to support it. We intend to turn this book about contemporary and future art into an art object itself both in terms of the scope of its writing and the high quality of its illustrations. In order to achieve this goal we are raising $15,000 (for production costs) and are asking the endorsement of people like you who are intrigued by these sweeping changes in the world of art, and who cherish the value of a thoughtful and beautiful art book.

 

A group of institutions have already pledged their support to this publication (we are still waiting on some others) so we don't need to achieve the full $15,000 through this Indiegogo campaign. Among these institutions, we can currently list:


College of Arts and Letters, 

California State University, Los Angeles.

$2,000

John Fowles Center for Creative Writing, 

Chapman University.

$500

Oldenborg Center, 

Pomona College.

$750

The Gould Center for Humanistic Studies,

Claremont McKenna College

$1,500

And from a group a private funders

$1,000


So we are aiming at raising at least another $5,000 through this campaign


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this project with friends and family. Help us spread the word... and be part of the future!



LASTLY: Our working thematic index should give you an idea about what these authors have in mind. Take a quick look:

TITLE INDEX

 

Hagi Kenaan

Time Comes to Art from the Future

 

Polona Tratnik

Manifesto for the Next Art

 

Peng Feng

Somaesthetics and Its Consequences in Contemporary Art

 

Glenn Harper

After the Expanded Field: Sculpture in the 21st Century

 

Mark Axelrod

Kindle, Kindle Burning Bright: Poetics of fiction on the 21st Century

 

Salima Hashmi

Art/Aesthetics in the next 100 years -A dialogue

(This text is the result of an extensive  round table with the Pakistani artists Rashid Rana, Huma Mulji, Quddus Mirza, Naazish Ataullah, and Ayesha Jatoi and Salima Hashmi)

 

Mieke Bal

Affect and the Space We Share: Three Forms of Installation Art (The Futurality of Affect)

 

 

Jan Garden Castro

Futurecast: Merging Subject with Object

 

 

Liliana Porter and Ana Tiscornia

Axonometry of the Future, or Prophecies for the 21st Century

 

Pablo Baler

Interrupted Reading: The Aesthetics of Metastasis

  

Sue Golding

Ana-Materialism and the Pineal Eye (Becoming Mouth-Breast)

 

 

Stelarc

ALIVENESS & AFFECT: ALTERNATE ART & ANATOMIES



THANK YOU!!!!!!

story:
You Love the Little Prince ?

Help us create the very first Official The Little Prince Art Toy !

Based on Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's original drawings from The Little Prince.

The Little Prince is one of the most beloved books in the world. Over 150 Million copies sold, 400 million readers and 260 different translations (when Harry Potter only has 68 translations for instance).

Very important : The Art Toy is being made with the exclusive authorization of the Antoine de Saint-Exupéry Estate in Paris France. 

This art toy is made of Vinyle, it's 10cm high, it comes with a square box. Full color.

Warning : This is not a toy, it's an ART TOY. It's for decoration and collection purposes. Not aimed to kids and babies.

This art toy is being made by artists from all around the globe. Produced by Muttpop in France, it's designed by Bill with sculpture work by Monster5 in Japan.

Creating a genuine Art Toy costs a lot and we ask for you help : preorder the ART TOY today and help us to finance the production.We need you to support this project to make it happen. Help us create this cute Art Toy and get it in the mail next September.

Share this, support us.

Coming in September 2012.

story:
Short Summary

I am Mwiza Nyirenda,a Malawian film maker and social rights activist. In 2013 I completed the film,Umunthu, a 30 minute first person documentary on homosexuality in Malawi that investigates the complexities of tolerance, acceptance and culture in relationship LGBTQ rights.

Umunthu has been selected for the Boston International Film Festival (BIFF),taking place April 11-21st. Attending this festival, and the screening of Umunthu is integrally important to the continued dialogue surrounding this human rights issue, on both a national and international scope. Presenting, screening and discussing Umunthu throughout Boston will help give voice to a perspective that is rarely heard, and needs to be heard, regarding the issue of homosexuality and how it is perceived in an African country. I anticipate meeting with several stake holders that will further our screening efforts in Malawi and in other countries throughout Africa as a result of attending this festival. It is also an amazing opportunity as a burgeoning artist to attend such a festival for networking, and to further develop my voice and abilities as a social change advocate.

In addition to the screening at BIFF I intend to screen the film,and host a panel discussion, at Harvard University in conjunction with Still Harbor. I will also leverage this opportunity to intern with internationally recognized film maker, and Executive Director of BIFF, Patrick Jerome.

In conjunction with this campaign, I am also seeking funding for this trip through the Prince Claus Fund and individual donors. Even if the full amount is not raised on Indigogo I am hopeful that I will still be able to attend the festival, but I need your help in making it possible! If we raise more than we expect, the additional funds will go to help bring Executive Director, Galia Boneh to Boston as well.

What We Need & What You Get

I am trying to raise $3,500 USD to cover expenses for the trip.

$2,000 USD will be used to pay forair fare
$1,500 USD will be used to cover meals, travel expenses while in Boston and between Boston and New York, and accommodation as necessary (when I'm not couch surfing!).

PERKS:

$25 - a signed poster

$100 - a copy of the DVD

$500 - a copy of the DVD and if in Boston, a chat with me over coffee or Dinner and a ticket to the film's screening at film festival.

$1000 -  Umunthu screening, discussion and Q&A session with film maker and social justice advocate, Mwiza Nyirenda (ME!),at a venue of your choice(available in Boston and New York, between April 19th-29th).

The Impact

The issue of homosexuality is divisive not only in Malawi but worldwide, and much of the debate has focused on African countries. In some African countries, such as Uganda and Nigeria, anti-gay movements are becoming increasingly influential on the state and the public. What the American and European public do not understand is that anti-gay campaigns are often perceived as acts of resistance to European and American dominance, and the public in some African countries is not as unanimously homophobic as they appear to be on the media. Umunthu presents how the issue is perceived and discussed in the Malawian context,and tries to shape an African response towards the issue of homosexuality through an indigenous pan African concept of Umunthu- which simply means I am because we are. It presents a variety of opinions, and shows how and why the issue becomes too politicized and emotionally charged.

The opportunity to screen the film, Umunthu for an international audience not only provides a rare chance for that audience to hear an African voice, but also challenges the image of Africa perpetuated by western media as a homophobic continent. Earlier this year,Umunthu was screened at the Pan African Film Festival in Los Angeles (http://www.paff.org/filmfest/2014-films/umunthu-an-african-response-to-homosexuality/). The audience at the festival expressed the feeling that the film challenges negative attitudes towards Africa.

Screening Umunthu at the Boston International Film Festival, Harvard University and other spaces in Boston and New York serves as a continuation of the film's goal to create sober platforms to discuss the issue of LGBTQ rights. Its not only about offering an African perspective to the ongoing discussion of the issue--but creating a cross-cultural exchange of ideas, moving towards a place of tolerance and acceptance for all.

In Malawi,Umunthu, as part of the UP program,at the Art & Global Health Centre Africa, has been screened in seven colleges. The following article demonstrates the discourse it has initiated: http://www.nyasatimes.com/2013/10/30/chanco-graduates-film-umunthu-revamps-debate-on-gays-in-malawi/

To learn more about Umunthu, and the Art and Global Health Center please visit our website and facebook pages: www.aghcafrica.org,https://www.facebook.com/pages/Umunthu/518816898197399 

https://www.facebook.com/aghcafrica,

Thank you so much in advance for your support.Your generosity shall not be taken for granted.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in Boston, please attend Umunthu screening at the festival on 18 April from 1:00 PM to 3:15 PM at the At the AMC/Loews Theater 175 Tremont St. Boston, MA 02108 and also attend the Boston International Film Festival which starts on 11 to 21 April 2014.
story_txt:
Short
Summary
I
am Mwiza Nyirenda,a Malawian film maker and social rights activist. In 2013 I completed the film,Umunthu, a 30 minute first
person documentary on homosexuality in Malawi that investigates the
complexities of tolerance, acceptance and culture in relationship LGBTQ rights.
Umunthu has been selected for the Boston
International Film Festival (BIFF),taking place April 11-21st. Attending this festival, and the
screening of Umunthu is integrally important to the continued dialogue
surrounding this human rights issue, on both a national and international
scope. Presenting, screening and discussing Umunthu throughout Boston will help
give voice to a perspective that is rarely heard, and needs to be heard,
regarding the issue of homosexuality and how it is perceived in an African
country. I anticipate meeting with several stake holders that will further our
screening efforts in Malawi and in other countries throughout Africa as a
result of attending this festival. It is also an amazing opportunity as a
burgeoning artist to attend such a festival for networking, and to further
develop my voice and abilities as a social change advocate.
In
addition to the screening at BIFF
I intend to screen the film,and
host a panel discussion, at Harvard University in conjunction with Still
Harbor. I will also leverage this opportunity to intern with internationally
recognized film maker, and Executive Director of BIFF, Patrick Jerome.
In conjunction with this campaign, I am also seeking
funding for this trip through the Prince Claus Fund and individual donors. Even
if the full amount is not raised on Indigogo I am hopeful that I will still be
able to attend the festival, but I need your help in making it possible! If we
raise more than we expect, the additional funds will go to help bring Executive
Director, Galia Boneh to Boston as well.
What We Need & What You Get
I am trying to
raise $3,500 USD to cover
expenses for the trip.
$2,000 USD will
be used to pay forair fare$1,500 USD will be used to cover meals, travel expenses while in Boston and
between Boston and New York, and accommodation as necessary (when I'm not couch
surfing!).
PERKS:
$25 - a signed poster
$100 - a copy of the DVD$500 - a copy of the DVD and if in Boston, a chat with me over coffee or Dinner and a ticket to the film's screening
at film festival.
$1000 -  Umunthu screening, discussion and Q&A session with film maker and social justice
advocate, Mwiza Nyirenda (ME!),at
a venue of your choice(available
in Boston and New York, between April 19th-29th).
The Impact
The
issue of homosexuality is divisive not only in Malawi but worldwide, and much
of the debate has focused on African countries. In some African countries, such
as Uganda and Nigeria, anti-gay movements are becoming increasingly influential
on the state and the public. What the American and European public do not
understand is that anti-gay campaigns are often perceived as acts of resistance
to European and American dominance, and the public in some African countries is
not as unanimously homophobic as they appear to be on the media. Umunthu presents how the issue is perceived and
discussed in the Malawian context,and tries to shape an African response
towards the issue of homosexuality through an indigenous pan African concept of Umunthu-
which simply means I
am because we are. It
presents a variety of opinions, and shows how and why the issue becomes too politicized and emotionally charged.
The opportunity to screen the film, Umunthu for an international audience
not only provides a rare chance for that audience to hear an African voice, but
also challenges the image of Africa perpetuated by western
media as a homophobic continent. Earlier this year,Umunthu was screened at the Pan
African Film Festival in Los Angeles (http://www.paff.org/filmfest/2014-films/umunthu-an-african-response-to-homosexuality/).
The audience at the festival expressed the feeling that the film challenges
negative attitudes towards Africa.
Screening Umunthu at the Boston International Film
Festival, Harvard University and other spaces in Boston and New York serves as a continuation of the film's goal to create
sober platforms to discuss the issue of LGBTQ rights. Its not only about offering an
African perspective to the ongoing discussion of the issue--but creating a cross-cultural exchange
of ideas, moving towards a place of tolerance and acceptance for all.
In
Malawi,Umunthu, as part of the UP program,at the
Art & Global Health Centre Africa, has been screened in seven colleges. The
following article demonstrates the discourse it has initiated: http://www.nyasatimes.com/2013/10/30/chanco-graduates-film-umunthu-revamps-debate-on-gays-in-malawi/
To learn more about Umunthu, and the Art and Global
Health Center please visit our website and facebook pages: www.aghcafrica.org,https://www.facebook.com/pages/Umunthu/518816898197399 https://www.facebook.com/aghcafrica,
Thank
you so much in advance for your support.Your
generosity shall not be taken for granted.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are in Boston, please attend Umunthu screening at the
festival on 18 April from 1:00 PM to 3:15 PM at the At the AMC/Loews Theater 175 Tremont St. Boston, MA 02108 and also attend the Boston International
Film Festival which starts on 11 to 21 April 2014.

story:
Short Summary

Namaste! We are Cirello Metalsmith. Two lovers connected under one passion - a vision to inspire positive intention through authentic, quality hand-made art.

Matthew Cirello has been making jewelry for over 10 years. Finding his passion while studying at Humbolt State University, his career started in 2007 as a studio artist of Spanish Village Art Center in San Diego, California. In 2008 he opened his first retail gallery with working studios where he met me, Jasmine, in 2009.

Matthew on his bench in the gallery.

Custom "Spirit" pendant in process by Jasmine.

Jasmine and Matthew in the gallery/studio.

We worked together selling and curating the works of other local talent while growing creatively and romantically closer. After five and a half years of managing a public space and developing the surrounding artist community, we have represented over 30 artists and participated in over 60 consecutive monthly art walks. This September we closed the gallery and moved our studio to our ranch in Jamul.


Many San Diego based artists were represented in our gallery showroom.


New studio in Jamul!



Our fundraising kick-off is just the beginning of our new chapter. Inspired by the creative community of Black Rock City, our experience at Burning Man 2014 solidified our commitment to serving our true life's passion together. And living it right now. But we cannot do it alone. We need the help of our surrounding community. You!

By donating to this project you will be supporting the arts as a viable part of society and spreading the power of positive collective conscious action.

What We Need

GOALS & OBJECTIVES

·  Mobile Jewelry Studio

  • Custom/restored RV, aluminum cabinets/shop, new tools, lighting
  • Enables demonstration and creation wherever we are
  • Scheduled use at Burning Man 2015
  • Travel across country to various art shows
  • Estimated Cost:  $20,000

·  ManifestStation:  A Portal to Your Passion

  • Interactive, collaborative art sculpture for Burning Man 2015
  • 8 individual laser-cut metal and sand-blasted glass sculptures represent positive intentions with words and symbols
  • When all interactions occur together a wooden Seed of Life in the center glows like the full moon and laser-cut wooden Flower of Life canopy hand painted with clouds is lit, giving participants the feeling of rising above the Earth, floating in the sky with the moon as OM begins. The sound of energy becoming matter. The beginning of manifest.
  • Sound healing space
  • Metal/glass sculptures for placement at main donor location(s) after event
  • Estimated Cost: $100,000

·  Art Sales

  • Custom commissions 
  • Wholesale accounts
  • Internet sales
  • Home jewelry parties
  • Sales Goal:  $5,000/month

·  Market our talents as a viable part of society

  • Update e-commerce website:  cirellometalsmith.com
  • Monthly video
  • Bi-monthly email campaign
  • Estimated Cost: $3,000 

·  Fundraising

  • $100,000 fundraising goal from IndieGoGo
  • $23,000 fundraising goal from private events & grants

What You Get

An opportunity to obtain our art for a limited time special offer. And be a part of the larger vision... Love.
$50 Offering:  "I Trust" Pendant, Limited Edition (Retail Value: $108)

$100 Offering:  "Waves of Change" Cuff (Retail Value: $168)

$200 Offering:  "Divine OM" Pendant (Retail Value: $288)


$400 Offering:  "Sky Gazing Upon the Flower" Pendant (Retail Value: $550)


$500 Offering:  "Sacred Shreeyantra" Pod (Retail Value: $678)


$1,000 Offering:  "Divine Collaboration" Pendant, One-of-a-kind (Retail Value: $1,500)


$2,000 Offering:  "Galactic Space Turtle" Pendant, One-of-a-kind (Retail Value: $3,300)


PARTY SPECIALS!
$1,500 Offering:  "Dragon Flower" Pendant, One-of-a-kind (Retail Value: $2,860)

    The Impact

    Our art is a symbol of the spiritual awakening of our time. By creating a tangible representation of a particular moment or thought, collectors obtain a “miniature time-capsule” expressing this intention into the future. Empowering us to share the messages of Love that come from honoring our collective Spirit each piece contains a story, a way of life, which can be appreciated through these wearable artworks and passed down over generations to come.


      Risks & Challenges

      As with any endeavor there are always challenges that may arise. Of course, we need to be aware that things may not always go as planned. Honestly, we have already experienced so many trials. Opening a high-end, retail art gallery was not an easy task and letting it go proved to be even more difficult.

      It is our hope that if we continue telling our story and working towards our goals we will inspire others to become involved because they believe in what we have to offer. And of course, by being adaptable and thinking of creative solutions to produce the most beneficial result, we always overcome.


      As long as we stay true to what we’ve created we know we will succeed. We can promise you, when it comes to growth there is no stopping us. We are inspiring the world through art.

      Love Life True,

      Jasmine and Matthew Cirello

It is our hope that if we continue telling our story and

story:
THE MOVE

Aloha!
Thank you so much for taking the time to even think about helping my move to California. I've thought long and hard about this and have finally decided to risk it all and try to make my dreams come true, but I realize that without you guys, my loyal and loving fans, I wouldn't even be close!

The reason I want to move to California is to more easily collab with some of my friends and maybe even some of your favorite YouTubers. I believe that this move is the leap of faith I need to take in order to make my videos funnier, more relatable, and overall a better experience for you guys!

You guys can play a huge part in this! Whether it's something like $5 to $100, ANYTHING HELPS! I'd love to have some of you be in my videos as well as perks for helping! The first few months are gonna be the most crucial and that's all I'm asking help for. Just to get on my feet in this whole new stage of my life.

Even if you can't help, simply sharing the video or campaign with others helps because they might be willing to help!

Again, thank you for even considering to help me and I love you all!
Will

story:
Nearing the End!

Thank you so much for checking out my campaign, and for sharing it. We're in the last week, so if you've been waiting to contribute, now is the time!
I've been combing through my images taken in Nova Scotia, and have so much material for projects to last me through the rest of the year. I'm also anxiously watching over a batch of bioluminescent mushrooms that I started from a sterile culture during my residency, and will be exploring paper, ink, and dyes made from mushrooms that I'll be cultivating and harvesting over the winter and next spring.
I've listed a special perk for the end of the campaign: your choice of three limited-edition, leather bound accordion fold books! I'm so very happy with them. I love presenting images in book forms--it allows for more intimate viewing and participation from the viewer. These are really special, and I hope you'll grab one before they're gone.

Update!

Hello! I'm having an amazing residency experience, and am so grateful to my supporters! I have been trekking through the bio regions of Nova Scotia, learning about bioluminescence, tides, squids, and other things that make this area so special. I've harvested birch bark and constructed wee little accordion fold books. I'm in the midst of experimenting with dyes made from mushrooms, and we'll be attempting to make some paper from mushrooms tomorrow. 
Along the way, I've made some splendid photographs that I'm very excited about. You can have one for your very own! Check out the perks for supporting my project. 

Summary

I'm an artist and a teacher. I've been invited to be one of five artists participating in an artist residency in Wolfville, Nova Scotia this summer. With local scientists and experts, we will explore the Bay of Fundy region, home to the world's biggest tides, amazing fossils, and a host of Canadian wildlife. 

Biophilia is open to artists who explore natural themes in their work. Attending artists will have time to work on individual projects while also getting valuable time to collaborate with each other. We will also work with experts in astronomy, biology, botany, mycology, and geology, gaining insight and inspiration for future projects. I'm so excited to see new landscapes, including some ancient sea beds and fossils I've never viewed in real life. I'll be exploring the topography and how the flora and fauna settle into it, looking for ways to extend my work. The residency will also give me great connections with like-minded artists, and who knows where that can lead.

This is a terrific opportunity for me to push my work further. I have three significant gallery shows in 2015-16, including my first solo show. This residency is a perfect catalyst for the work I'll need to complete in the next few months. 

What I Need and How Much it Costs

I've never been to Nova Scotia. One thing I've discovered is it's about as far away from SW Oregon as a body can get in North America before ending up in Greenland. I have travel and residency expenses to cover:

  • $1000 residency fee to pay for residency expenses
  • $1100 airfare (RT Portland to Halifax)
  • $535 for lodging during travel to and from the residency
  • $100 for ground transportation and meals not covered by residency
Total funding needed: $2735
I'm eligible for up to $1500 from a faculty professional development fund via my college. I've applied for this grant, but receiving it isn't a certainty and it won't cover the entire expense. There are no other applicable grant opportunities at this time, so I'm looking to raise the funds via my work.
What's in it for you? No chocolate bars or wrapping paper here--you'll get art! All funds will be used to pay for the residency and the production/shipping of thank you gifts. Any additional funds will go towards printing and framing works from the residency for exhibition.

HUGE Thanks!
I'm offering some great perks in exchange for your support; be sure to check them out in that section.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know we all get hit up for money on a regular basis, and appreciate that many folks have no funds to give. You can always help by sharing my campaign! I so appreciate you for reading about my project, and I hope you'll follow along as this residency leads me in new artistic directions.

story:
I have come up with a totally unique use of nail art that has NEVER been done before. I've come up with a way for people to afford their favorite piece of artwork... NO MATTER HOW EXPENSIVE IT IS.

I've created a bridge between the artist and the community, and I want to share it with you. I want to tell you my dream and what i'm doing to make it come true. This is an endeavor straight from the heart, to help better the world we live in and bring communities together.

**Two Lane Black-Top to Paradise is a cross-country project with a mission to help in the growth and strengthen local artist communities throughout the United States by helping them engage with the community around them to gain more support, all through... NAIL ART.**

The road-trip kicks off Saturday, April 26th in Oceanside, CA, at The Hill Street Country Club art gallery. The trip will be a little over a month long. At each location on our itinerary, we will be staying for a MINIMUM of two days where an event has been scheduled with 78 West Collective. During the days prior to the event, we will be applying nail art appliqués of the artist being showcased, for event promotors and guests who have confirmed their attendance to the event. We will provide artists and promoters with photos of the nails showcasing the art being featured during the event. The purpose behind this is to raise awareness and excite the community for the upcoming event. During the event, we will be doing nails for guests attending, as well as hosting as much as we can manage in between doing the nails.. After the event has finished, proceeds will be split, we will retire to bed, perhaps some breakfast the following morning and some proper goodbyes to send us off to the next destination. 

We will be stopping off in the following locations beginning April 26th 2014:

Vista, CA | Los Angeles, CA | Death Valley, CA | Flagstaff, AZ | Albuquerque, NM | Austin, TX | New Orleans, LA | Savannah, GA | Wilmington, NC | Outerbanks, NC | Virginia Beach, VA | Richmond, VA | Washington, D.C | Philadelphia, Pennsylvania | Brooklyn, New York | Chicago, Illinois | Coeur D'alene, ID | 

My team and I will be transforming nail beds into "canvas" to showcase art during a gallery opening and the weeks following. A portion of the proceeds from our contribution to the event will be split between the featured artist, and the local artist community. We will be working on the road to help artists better organize their event, and work harmoniously with their venue provider and their community.

Paradise is a two lane black-top away, and we can't wait to meet you there...Please help fund the dream that keeps on giving.

If you're strapped for cash, ANYTHING would help...!! Recommendations of where to camp, cool must see's along the way, events relating to our project, trust worthy mechanic friends along our route that will help fix our car if it breaks down, your Auntie who makes an amazing portuguese bean soup, mix cd's (zip files), friends to meet, artists/art district recommendations that would care to be apart of this project, bands to see, words of encouragement...

xoxo See yah soon!


Links:

Website: 78westcollectiveco.com

Instagram: 78westcollective

E-mail: 78westcollective@gmail.com


IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO REQUEST US TO PLAN AN EVENT IN YOUR CITY!! Artists, and venues who wish to be apart of our nationwide effort to strengthen the artist community, please contact me at the following e-mail as soon as possible: 78westcollective@gmail.com
