Our rates are normalized to $9 shipping in the U.S., and $12 shipping for the rest of the world. In addition, we'll be paying for any EU Customs (if you're outside of the EU/US, normal customs will still apply).How did we do this? We'll be shipping ordered decks to a distributor in the EU that will ship full packages out, paying for the base shipping expense along with the initial customs fees - it reduces the costs by at least $15 per package. Please note that if you order a copy after our initial campaign/post-campaign store and initial shipment and need it shipped internationally, the price will be around $35 to ship both the box and the book.Please note that all card previews are subject to change. We have, however, attempted to portray as many of these pieces as accurately as we could.Add-OnsWe have partnered with Backerkit, a company that helps with backer support, and will be doing surveys (including add-ons) and the pre-order/post-order store through their services. You will be emailed a link to a survey to fill it out and, at that time, you'll be able to add any extra selections you'd like. TL;DR: You are not adding these now, and can adjust your number and quantities in the days after the campaign! :)The pricing list is below for your reference! The below are unlimited but we will not be able to reproduce them after the campaign (they are pledge exclusives). All selections made within the campaign were reset with the import.
Postcard Signature ($3): We’ll personally address your postcard to whoever you’d like.
Extra Postcards ($2 each): The backs will be blank, so you can do whatever you’d like with them.
Extra Vinyl Stickers ($2.50 each): Raptors and quaggan/choya; one is included with physical packs if unlocked by default
Stickers ($4): Ranger Tarot pets and Breakfast Mounts, 1 sheet each
Standard Pins ($7): World Completion (additional – one comes standard with the Tyrian Tarot deck), Res Me, Mastery/Laurel pin, baby catmander griffon, black lion trading coin pin, Apples for Tybalt - 1.25"
Specialty Pins ($10): Eternity – 2", rainbow anodized; [Coming soon!] - 2", glow in the dark
Digital Pack ($5): Includes the cover as a wallpaper, the card backs as phone res items, a few cards as wallpapers and (potentially) some desktop wallpapers from the book designs
Prints ($10 for 5"x7" on archival, fine art quality): Additional sizes will be available dependent on region.
Tarot Cloth ($13): As voted on by the community, we'll be making a Omadd's Map cloth - available only through the surveys as add-ons (material pending dependent on swatches - we're discussing with some pros on how to make this work to get the best options available to us)
Pin SelectionFinal selections are made through the add-on survey that will be sent out to all backers at the end of the campaign. You can make all adjustments and additions at that time!There are two default pins that you can pick from, as well as four additional pins that are unlocked through goals and Eternity. There is one last pin unlockable in the final stretch goal.

Stretch Goal: World Completion Pin -- Now added to all Tyrian Tarot packages!

Selection I (available): Mastery & Laurel Pin (ideas & designs by the mods)


Selection II (available): "Res me" halo pin (ideas & designs by the mods)


Selection III (available): Black Lion Trading Coin Pin (idea submitted anonymously, designed by the mods)


Selection IV (available): Catmander Baby Griffon (idea submitted by MuffinWifey, designed by the mods)


Selection V (available): Apples for Tybalt (idea submitted by Digital Flower, designed by the mods)

Selection VI (available as add-on only): Eternity (note: made of rainbow anodized metal - each one is unique, 1.75")

Selection VII (available as add-on only): Flameseeker Prophecies (note: 1.75", glow in the dark)
Note: All images are still in production.Print ChoicesFinal selections are made through the add-on survey that will be sent out to all backers at the end of the campaign. You can make all adjustments and additions at that time!For the print add ons, you’re able to select a print of one of the following. It will be updated if any participants add their images to the list (and the images will be updated to reflect progression - many are still works in progress). You'll be able to see full mini-previews during selection in the surveys in May.
These are unlimited and printed on 5"x7” paper, shipped with the packages in August.
Options will be available in the survey for selection, but also for a larger size (for framing)
Artists offering prints were allowed to decide if they'd donate their "net" or keep it. This is up to their discretion and not disclosed.
LARGER PRINTS will be available starting June 16. We are currently evaluating EU orders.Commission OpportunitiesCommissions are offered through the campaign for select artists who have opted in. These commissions come with the deck and any unlocks, as well as a printed copy of your illustration (and digital). We will put you in contact with your artist so that you can come to an agreement on ideas, and your commission will begin shortly after the conclusion of the campaign (so we can pay them). There are five tiers, listed below, with the artists who are available/reserved. NOTICE: All 23 commissions are reserved.Reserved Commissions (Reference)Tier 5: H1fey (Wojtek Depczyński); Tier 5: Casondra Logan; Tier 4: H1fey (Wojtek Depczyński); Tier 4: Casondra; Tier 3: Ohm; Tier 3: Ranya Ni; Tier 2: H1fey (Wojtek Depczyński); Tier 2:  Celebril; Tier 2: Shahina; Tier 2: Sketching Sands; Tier 2:  Thavie; Tier 1:  Celebril; Tier 1:  Sketching Sands; Tier 1:  Rusavia; Tier 1: Ohm; Tier 1 (x2): Shahina; Tier 1 (x3): Kyla Frank; Tier 1 (x2): Route 13; Tier 1: Diana Glebowicz
With the Indiegogo campaign, we’ve designed a variety of goals in three categories. We recognize that our community comes from all over, and there are a number of places you could come from, and we wanted to make this experience a fun one. Please note that once we unlock a goal, it gets added to physical decks or becomes an option without any adjustment from you. There's no need to adjust your pledge. Stretch goals are the traditional type of funding goal, directly coming from the monetary value involved with the campaign. These goals only happen after we are fully funded for the base production of the decks.Pledge goals are our spin on community goals. Every pledge, whether it’s $1 or $100, counts to these, and there are a lot of great unlocks here. Dominantly, the team have come together to create extra cards including gods, dragons and characters they really wanted to see in the deck.Social media goals started on April 20th. We have two stickers that will be posted to social media (one for each platform). If they hit the requirements listed, they’ll get unlocked for every Tyrian Tarot bundle.Our wonderful contributors of the GW2 Tarot Club project began work on the deck early this year, pouring their love for the game and creative power into the pieces for this collaboration. Both new and returning artists were specially selected, aiming to create a cohesive deck in appearance, with care and consideration for the world we are representing. See below to visit their professional profiles - for their various social media platforms, please check out our full contributor listing on Tumblr.Moderation:Mel Sayre (Zorav) ◊◊ Angelique van der Mee ◊◊ Aun Hana ◊◊ Sara Danger ◊◊ ThunderpotArtists (including participating moderation):Alassa ◊◊ allpurposepanda ◊◊ Andrés Agostini ◊◊ Anez ◊◊ Angelique van der Mee ◊◊ Anneliese Mak ◊◊ Aun Hana ◊◊ BleachedRainbows ◊◊ Casondra  ◊◊ Celebril ◊◊ Changer the Elder ◊◊ Chilkat ◊◊ chrisqi ◊◊ Cortez ◊◊ Diana Glebowicz (Larea) ◊◊ Elodie Mondoloni ◊◊ evermeer ◊◊ Evi ◊◊ Favena ◊◊ Fell ◊◊ Flutti ◊◊ gears2gnomes ◊◊ Grise ◊◊ Htg17 ◊◊ Isvoc ◊◊ Jem ◊◊ Josephine-frays ◊◊ Juuni ◊◊ Katalean ◊◊ kingbaest ◊◊ kinixuki ◊◊ KoboldArt ◊◊ Kyla Frank ◊◊ Landylachs ◊◊ Lemoncholy ◊◊ Mamath ◊◊ Marta Milczarek ◊◊ Mike Nash ◊◊ Ohm ◊◊ Owlma ◊◊ PlaviGmaz ◊◊ Ragous ◊◊ Ranya Ni ◊◊ Route13 ◊◊ Rurush_Ichi ◊◊ Rusavia ◊◊ Sara Danger ◊◊ Sarianne ◊◊ Sayael ◊◊ Shahina ◊◊ Shunkaku ◊◊ Skaven Zverov ◊◊ Sketching Sands ◊◊ Sleepsunn ◊◊ Smirtouille ◊◊ sockpoppet ◊◊ Tealful Eyes ◊◊ Thavie ◊◊ Thunderpot ◊◊ Tim Kaminski ◊◊ Travis Purvis ◊◊ Veer ◊◊ Weston T. Jones  ◊◊ Wojtek Depczyński ◊◊ Yakitty ◊◊ Yanli Wang ◊◊ Yazzart ◊◊ ZaaraWriters & Editors:Ben Lee (Incendium) ◊◊ Kora (GuildLores) ◊◊ Mel Sayre (Zorav)Promotional Cosplayer:Enayla (with photography by Al Lin) The Guild Wars 2 story begins with the Commander, pushed into the role of tirelessly saving Tyria time and time again. From the moment we grabbed our first weapon, we led a path of discovery: exploring hundreds of places in the face of gods and dragons, sharing a journey with countless others. However, what made this story great was more than that – it was the stories forged from being in a community many call home. The cards of this deck attempt to encapsulate that story – of places traveled, moments remembered, characters never forgotten.With this project, we promise to deliver the best project we can, at the highest quality we can afford. These aren’t meant to be “just community projects,” but something that you can pull off your shelves for years to come. We hope the breakdown below can provide any additional clarification on our operations, but elsewise, please let us know so we can address it.Fund AllocationNote: The image above is an estimation for sales given a 750 deck order, unlocking at least the 2-piece box and the perfect bound, foiled physical book, as well as the free world completion pin. The charity margin goes up if we increase our deck and print orders.Notice on 11/2018: A donation of $42,000 has been made to the International Fund for Animal Welfare. This was 33% of our overall budget donated to the cause.TimelineRisks & ChallengesThe risks and challenges of any project at this size usually falls to logistics and planning. While the moderation team of Tyrian Tarot are by no means immune to potential pitfalls, we have done the best we can to safeguard the project in as many ways as we can.With a previous project completed, this is the second Guild Wars 2 project led by the same leadership. Sponsored by ArenaNet, we’ll be working to fulfill all of our promised tiers in a prompt and efficient manner - the Wintersday Zine in December 2017 was shipped out only 17 days after orders closed, exactly on schedule, and we aim to keep that promise with this project in staying as close to our dictated timeline as possible. In the event of delays, we’ll always be prompt with updating anyone through the updates on this page and social media.By the time the campaign ends, all artwork will be completed, and all that remains will be the proofing and assembly of the book. Our ultimate goal is to do right by all of our fabulous artists while giving to a good cause. To foster that we’re working with a high-quality printer that will produce the best deck/book that they can, and have an experienced team to put it all together.With that, the funding of this project is in your hands, and we love you for considering to support us. If you have any questions at any time, we are always happy to answer them at gw2collective@gmail.com.

story:
INSPIRE - EMPOWER - REJUVENATE

“COTTON"

This performance/installation will premier at JackNy in Brooklyn in early fall of 2014.

The first major supporters for the project are Jackny.org,  www.franklinfurnace.org and a BRIC Media Arts Artist Fellowship.

Please support the creation of Monstah Black's newest performance piece “Cotton!"

INTRODUCTION TO THE PROJECT:

“Cotton” uses images, stories and songs to shape a non-linear installation with sounds and projected images. It uses cotton balls, tobacco and additional objects cultivated by slaves as its main source for construction and movement created from images reflecting celebration, fellowship, hardship and struggle.

The creation of this multi-media performance piece will involve travel to the Shirley Plantation and forests in Virginia to gather moving images and photography of performers who will be wearing majestic cotton ball regalia.

BACKGROUND:

Choreographer, performance artist, vocalist, teacher, night club impresario, club fashion designer Monstah Black a.k.a Reginald Ellis Crump was born and raised in Colonial Williamsburg, Virginia. His grandparents worked in the Colonial setting for years and his aunts and uncles worked on plantations and on college campuses (William and Mary College) built by slaves. Monstah is not far removed from the days of his ancestors who picked “Cotton”.

Monstah has performed internationally with acclaimed artists such as visual artist iROZEALb creator of the Battle of Yestermore performed at Basil, Miami. He’s worked with McArthur award winning Liz Lerman of the Liz Lerman Dance Exchange, Maida Withers Dance Construction, Grisha Colemans Echo::System and he is also a member of HOWDOYOUSAYYAMINAFRICAN, currently  screening their film,Good Stock on the Dimension Floor: An Operaas part of The 2014 Whitney Biennial. Monstah is also guest vocalist with electro dance band Girls Like Bass.

Now based in Brooklyn, New York Monstah is an Artist Fellow at BRIC Media Arts and supported in part by Franklin Furnace Foundation.  

Through the development of “Cotton” (a performance installation of audio/visual/kinesthetic poetry, metaphorically representing a troubled peoples agonizing journey to ascension), this new show further brings into the context the The Acid Box Cabaret  (A.B.C) created in 1994.  

A.B.C was an evening of whimsical song, dance, media and DIY lighting, all triggered on stage byMonstah Black (not unlike Pee Wee’s Playhouse). The work touched on everything from gender-bending phobias, racism and the clinical pristine-ness of being politically correct.  ABC garnered support from the District Of Columbia Commission on the Arts and Humanities for it’s creation.  This work of poetry and dancing marked the beginning of Monstah's performance activism to encourage social change.

“Cotton” is believed to have been planted in Virginia as early as 1607.  Some say that cotton was grown by the indigenous people of “American” soil as early as 1500. When Monstah speaks of cotton, he looks at references to slavery not the history of cotton taught in grade schools in the south. He reflects on miles and miles of fields, cultivated by a displaced people as they roast in the sun, stuck in a repetition for hours and hours for fear of being beaten by the master. This is the image he chooses to turn inside out. He takes the elements that ring negative in his heart and soul and flip them into positive images for empowerment. Indeed, he aims to inspire, empower and rejuvenate, no matter the age, race, sexual, political or religious orientation.

Monstah has been creating interdisciplinary shows that empower for the entire span of his artistic career. His shows address issues ranging from homophobia, bullying, teen suicide, classism and racism. They are built around original electronic compositions, experimental movement/dance, vocal exploration, costume design (made from found materials) and media (video and photography).

Please support the creation of Monstah Black's “Cotton!"




What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5000 by April 1st.

With your donations we will be able to cover costs that include travel to Virginia, purchasing supplies, paying for accommodation’s, and compensating the artists needed to bring “Cotton” to fruition.

Travel

Round trip NYC to Virginia $180.00. 3 dancers and a videographer. Total: $540

Accommodations

3 nights in hotel $708 for 2 rooms

Artists Fees

-$100 a day for 3 days, 4 artists $1200

-per diem $45 a day $540

Costume Design

 (supplies and construction for 3 costumes $670.66 each ) $2012

Miscellaneous $540


Total $5000

If we do not reach our goal, funds raised will be put towards travel and compensation for all artists involved.


The Impact

“Cotton” is my idea of remixing images of slavery, morphing them into iconography that empowers the individual, a people and each of our spirits as we move into the future. My hope is to  shed some of the detriment that has shackled our souls for generation after generation. Your donation will allow this project to inspire and encourage others to find a sense of empowerment by re-imagining the spirit that walks with them as an African American. Enabling the African American to ascend as a people. This project aims to provoke a dialogue across the spectrum of ethnicities, religious and spiritual beliefs.

My belief is that “African Americans” are living with the open wounds of our ancestors. Education, personal relationships and a sense of community suffers amongst African American people. Are we caught in an interminable cycle, unable to escape a feeling of displacement due to the slave trade? Are we unable to find the necessary means to heal? Does this repetitive cycle manifest in ways that keeps us fighting against each other? The open wounds create disconnect between the African American male and female. In many cases it causes disrespect, miscommunication and misunderstanding. For years in the educational system we have studied misleading history books that painted only a portion of our history, keeping us in the dark (pun intended) on a large percentage of our ancestry. Devastation, humiliation, degradation that we have encountered as a people for 100’s of years is in our DNA. This leaves us unable to escape a sense of inferiority in many cases and often causes us to act out, feeding into a stereotype that has been thrust upon us.

Throughout my career I have produced projects that incorporated original music, choreography, video and installation. I have been building work that has socio-political content couched in absurdity, whimsy, fantasy and humor. On the surface many of these works were filled with eye candy, with hints of underground club scenes and pop culture. My creative career is a landscape that has ventured through comedy, horror, sci-fi, sensuality and drama. I believe “Cotton” could possibly be the pinnacle of my creative expression. I will not be able to achieve this project without the support of my family, friends and community of supporters.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word tell the world that “Cotton” is coming in 2014!

  • Donate time (constructing installation for performance, threading cotton balls)

  • Donate bags of cotton.

  • Donate wire

  • Network Building (Galleries, Universities) Cotton has to live.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

  • Like Cotton Pickin on Facebook (as of today I have 3,382 friends on my Monstah black facebook page. If each friend gave $3 to this project we will raise $9,846 allowing us to also invest in putting looped video footage onto tablets that can be mounted onto walls as well as open the installation in other cities)

  • Follow Cotton Pickin on Tumblr

story:
My name is Danielle A. Scruggs and I am a photographer, photo editor, and writer living and working in Chicago. This campaign is to raise money for the tuition to attend an artist residency program at the Vermont Studio Center this summer.  


The VSC artist in residence program provides a safe space for artists from around the world to live and make work in Johnson, VT.  Artists are provided with studios and facilities and are encouraged to come to the residency without a specific idea or project in mind to allow artistic growth, development, and exploration.  

**Click each perk to see all included items**


There is a tuition fee and I have been fortunate enough to have a third of it covered by the Vermont Studio Center. I have also already paid a deposit to hold my space because I am committed to continuing to grow as an artist and sustain my career in photography. The money I'm raising through this campaign will go towards covering the remainder of my tuition as well as travel to and from Johnson, VT and materials for creating the perks.  

Former Chicago Bulls player Craig Hodges for Chicago Reader


GOAL & PERKS
I need to raise $3800 in seven weeks.  
The majority of the funds raised ($3100) will go towards covering the remainder of my tuition. The rest of the funds raised will go towards a roundtrip ticket between Chicago and Vermont, the cost of film, development, photo paper (both print and digital), and other materials that will help me create new work in my studio space, which will include a zine of both previously unpublished and new work created during the residency:

$3100 - the remainder of the residency tuition

$300 - roundtrip airfare from Chicago to Vermont 

$300 - materials for the production of perk items and new work 

$100 - IndieGoGo fees


In return, I am offering the following:

  • Archival inkjet prints (8 x 10 & 16 x 20) of any image from my portfolio, daniellescruggs.com 
  • Postcards
  • A zine created during the residency of older and new work.
  • A one-hour portrait session at a location of your choosing, provided you’re based in Chicago, IL. 

All prints are archival inkjet prints with a quarter inch border on top and sides.  All content comes signed with a personal thank you note.    

Personal work

Personal work


THE IMPACT
I took a leap into faith (shout out to Kierkegaard) this year and decided to pursue an independent career as a photographer after spending ten years working as a photo editor/photo coordinator for various institutions.

Photography has been a lifeline for me, in all honesty. Being able to create images of Black and brown people in dignified, powerful ways and visually tell our stories in all their nuance and glory is what has motivated me to stay persistent, despite the challenges I have faced being a Black woman in an industry that has been predominantly white and male.

And I know that being able to spend four weeks in Johnson, VT will be a chance to dive back into making art outside of the parameters of an assignment. Having the space to slow down, research, read, and experiment without the pressures of a deadline or the fear of failing is something I think is a crucial part of any artist's continuing education. And being able to fellowship with different artists who work in different mediums will enrich my process immensely. I invite you to partner with me by pledging any amount you're willing so I continue on my path as a visual storyteller.

Even if I don't make my goal, I will of course still fulfill the perks that people have already donated. And I will do my best to make up the difference. 

Artist Gerald Williams for the New York Times


CAN'T DONATE MONETARILY? Help spread the word! 
I totally understand that not everyone will be able to donate.  I would love for you to support by spreading the word via Instagram, Facebook, or Twitter.  Spreading the word and donating that time is equally as effective as donating monetarily!

ABOUT DANIELLE A. SCRUGGS
Danielle A. Scruggs is a photographer, photo editor, art director, and writer based in Chicago, IL. She graduated from Howard University with a degree in print journalism and from Maryland Institute College of Art with a master's degree in digital art.

She has exhibited at Flashpoint Gallery, the Center for Photography at Woodstock, A.I.R. Gallery, Arlington Arts Center, the National Institutes of Health, Roman Susan Gallery, and the Los Angeles Center for Digital Art. She also contributes photo editing and art direction to the Southern Foodways Alliance as its first-ever Visuals Editor.

She was previously the Senior Photo Editor at ESPN's The Undefeated and Director of Photography at the Chicago Reader. She is also the founder and editor of Black Women Directors, an online resource highlighting Black women in film.

She is a member of several groups working to create equity within the visual storytelling field, including Authority Collective, Diversify.Photo and Women Photograph. 

THANK YOU
Thank you all very much for your continued support, donations and sharing this campaign. I appreciate you!
story_txt:
My name is Danielle A. Scruggs and I am a photographer, photo editor, and writer living and working in Chicago. This campaign is to raise money for the tuition to attend an artist residency program at the Vermont Studio Center this summer.  The VSC artist in residence program provides a safe space for artists from around the world to live and make work in Johnson, VT.  Artists are provided with studios and facilities and are encouraged to come to the residency without a specific idea or project in mind to allow artistic growth, development, and exploration.  **Click each perk to see all included items**There is a tuition fee and I have been fortunate enough to have a third of it covered by the Vermont Studio Center. I have also already paid a deposit to hold my space because I am committed to continuing to grow as an artist and sustain my career in photography. The money I'm raising through this campaign will go towards covering the remainder of my tuition as well as travel to and from Johnson, VT and materials for creating the perks.  Former Chicago Bulls player Craig Hodges for Chicago ReaderGOAL & PERKSI need to raise $3800 in seven weeks.  The majority of the funds raised ($3100) will go towards covering the remainder of my tuition. The rest of the funds raised will go towards a roundtrip ticket between Chicago and Vermont, the cost of film, development, photo paper (both print and digital), and other materials that will help me create new work in my studio space, which will include a zine of both previously unpublished and new work created during the residency:$3100 - the remainder of the residency tuition$300 - roundtrip airfare from Chicago to Vermont $300 - materials for the production of perk items and new work $100 - IndieGoGo feesIn return, I am offering the following:
Archival inkjet prints (8 x 10 & 16 x 20) of any image from my portfolio, daniellescruggs.com 

Postcards
A zine created during the residency of older and new work.
A one-hour portrait session at a location of your choosing, provided you’re based in Chicago, IL. 
All prints are archival inkjet prints with a quarter inch border on top and sides.  All content comes signed with a personal thank you note.    Personal workPersonal workTHE IMPACTI took a leap into faith (shout out to Kierkegaard) this year and decided to pursue an independent career as a photographer after spending ten years working as a photo editor/photo coordinator for various institutions.Photography has been a lifeline for me, in all honesty. Being able to create images of Black and brown people in dignified, powerful ways and visually tell our stories in all their nuance and glory is what has motivated me to stay persistent, despite the challenges I have faced being a Black woman in an industry that has been predominantly white and male.And I know that being able to spend four weeks in Johnson, VT will be a chance to dive back into making art outside of the parameters of an assignment. Having the space to slow down, research, read, and experiment without the pressures of a deadline or the fear of failing is something I think is a crucial part of any artist's continuing education. And being able to fellowship with different artists who work in different mediums will enrich my process immensely. I invite you to partner with me by pledging any amount you're willing so I continue on my path as a visual storyteller.Even if I don't make my goal, I will of course still fulfill the perks that people have already donated. And I will do my best to make up the difference. Artist Gerald Williams for the New York TimesCAN'T DONATE MONETARILY? Help spread the word! I totally understand that not everyone will be able to donate.  I would love for you to support by spreading the word via Instagram, Facebook, or Twitter.  Spreading the word and donating that time is equally as effective as donating monetarily!ABOUT DANIELLE A. SCRUGGSDanielle A. Scruggs is a photographer, photo editor, art director, and writer based in Chicago, IL. She graduated from Howard University with a degree in print journalism and from Maryland Institute College of Art with a master's degree in digital art.She has exhibited at Flashpoint Gallery, the Center for Photography at Woodstock, A.I.R. Gallery, Arlington Arts Center, the National Institutes of Health, Roman Susan Gallery, and the Los Angeles Center for Digital Art. She also contributes photo editing and art direction to the Southern Foodways Alliance as its first-ever Visuals Editor.She was previously the Senior Photo Editor at ESPN's The Undefeated and Director of Photography at the Chicago Reader. She is also the founder and editor of Black Women Directors, an online resource highlighting Black women in film.She is a member of several groups working to create equity within the visual storytelling field, including Authority Collective, Diversify.Photo and Women Photograph. THANK YOUThank you all very much for your continued support, donations and sharing this campaign. I appreciate you!

story:
Aerin Sizelove was born in a small town in Ohio.  She wanted more in her life than living in a small town where no one seemed to do much in the world.  She went to college at the Illinois Institute of Art in Chicago.  Though she loved living in the city she had always dreamed of living in San Francisco since she was 12.  After she graduated college she bought a plane ticket and packed up what she could in a few boxes and moved out to San Francisco in 2004.  Some of the earliest friendships helped her survive the difficulties of moving to a new city.  After years of working to survive and working in corporate jobs, she came up with this idea for a company which could help her pursue her passion for event planning and art.  Pink Elephant Art Nights is based off of her arts & craft nights which have been hosted in her home.  She hosted these events for several years and invited friends to bring others.  After meeting some amazing people through these events she decided why not bring these events to others and enjoy great food in the process.  So she decided to quit her day job which was making her miserable after the support of her amazing friends.  This is how it all began.  Now it’s up to you to be part of this and help create something that she hopes will become a lifelong community and place for other new transplants and old locals to cast aside the stress of work and enjoy the benefits of building relationships and creating amazing art.

Pink Elephant Art is in still in the early stages of creation and is around to bring people together who share a common interest in arts & crafts.  Often we all get caught up in our busy day to day and are searching for a creative outlet that also helps bring a fulfilling social interaction all into one.  With the help and support of many amazing people a seed of an idea have created the beginnings to an amazing company and organization.  To join together fantastic people who are searching to find others of like mind to share, build and well enjoy great food and drinks in each other’s company.  One day I hope not only to just host arts & crafts night but to help connect people and help them find new friends and networking opportunities through this community.  Coming soon will be a crowd funding to get this project rolling below.  Currently we are expecting to have the first official Pink Elephant Art Nights up and running as soon as September 2016.

I've been hosting an event planning for years and all I need are the means for supplies.  I hope to host events from 10 - 20 people ranging from a variety of arts and crafts.  This will be of course involving restaurants with amazing food and drinks.

If the campaign succeeds I will have what I need to get this rolling.  The more funds received the more I can plan events and the lower the costs to those attending can be.  Either way I plan on starting this company and hope that with word of mouth I can raise enough to get started and have enough events that everyone can participate and enjoy what I've enjoyed hosting arts & crafts night from my living room for years.

story:
I always tell everyone that my Instagram feed is a creativity outlet of mine and just a product of the things I've learned from the internet. Never had I imagined doing an exhibit. Just so happen that Samtoy Books asked me if I could do an exhibit in lined with their December activities. It would be my first time doing such thing. 

  

Being said I'm going to shoulder mostly of the expenses and it would be best if I could ask some assistance especially on shouldering the finances. I have sent a few Direct Messages to Instagram people and friends, to ask assistance. Some have replied and suggested doing a crowd funding. Thus I'm here. 

Objective especially for Instagrammers like me:

Other than showing my photos in the exhibit, I really wanted to tell our community that Instagram is a platform for artists. I wanted them to be inspired by my photos, inspired to use Instagram, cause I myself is an Instagram taught kid. That for not its lessons I would not have grown my art and I wouldn't be here asking some help for the exhibit. 

Printing Formats

As of plan I'm printing some of the photos in medium scale a 15x15 in canvas. Im printing the photos in a canvas so that they'll be presented in a way without frames, edge to edge. 


They've also asked me to include my starting photos and show transition of it. I'm planning of a 5x5 photo paper prints clipped on a frame on something like this. 

  


Where do your money go??

I have already started scouting as reflected above and presently my estimate expenses would be more or less 15,000 Ph Peso or around $350. 

If It happens that you don't have credit card, you can do a Bank Deposit or go for Money Transfer. Hit me up in Instagram or in Facebook. (Links below)

This is a breakdown. I still don't know pricing of the others materials such as the frames for the small photos and the campaign materials. 

The remaining money is an allowance for the processing fee here in Indiegogo.   

A bit of background

By profession I'm a Nurse but here in the Philippines, nurses don’t get paid much especially when you’re just a fresh board passer. To tell you, I receive about 5000 PhP or about $120 a month. They don’t even call it salary, they call it allowance. And for the past three months, I have not received any single centavo from my employer, which is also tantamount to being a volunteer nurse. And just so yesterday our contract just ended. As much as I would like to pour all my salary on this one, It is very uncertain when will I receive it or if  I will ever receive it. 

I know money is a bit hard to find these days. But it would really mean a lot to me if you’ll look into this. Please don't hesitate to ask if you have queries. 

Warmest regards from my warm country,

Russel Andrew Villena 

Email: rahra_russel@yahoo.com

Instagram: @rahrarussel


PS.

now get this WORK said Iggy A.

story:
The project:

Thor and Greta is conceived as a 35mm photography and music video exhibition. It is part of an ongoing project called Portraits.

One image is not enough to express the complexity of a being, so I wanted to create whole exhibitions that could be experienced as a journey into a character's psychological reality. 

Weaving photography, video and music within a gallery space, enables a complete and multi faceted exploration of a person's inner struggle, from their most dense and foggy paralysis, to their most life affirming powerful state.

The photographs, which compose the first part of the exhibition, fix and isolate the various emotional patterns that suffocate and constrict the character.

The music video breaks this silence, this fixity: these states are not rigid manacles within which the character is stuck, but moving and living phases of life, that the character can master.

The whole project is an ongoing collaboration with musician Lottie Bowater. Not only was she the subject of the first portrait (Elise), but she is also the music composer who has been with me since the beginning, creating sounds that so accurately mirror and condense in audio form the emotional content I attempt to express visually. 

The work process with the characters is very intense and intimate, none of them are actors, all express very real and personal emotions.

--------

Portrait #1:

The first portait of the series is called Elise: 

A few of the photos:

A few stills from the music video:

And a short extract from the video and the song composed by Lottie Bowater:


----------


Portrait #2:

The second portrait of the series is called: Thor and Greta.

Two characters this time (though both ultimately embody different sides of the same being).

I am finished with Greta's photography part.

A few of the pictures:

And a mood board for the Thor work which will be done in August:


--------

 

You:

At this stage what still needs to be done is: 

Record the music.

Film Greta's video part.

Photograph + Film Thor.


1) The crew: 

For the work to be as powerful as it can be, it is important that we isolate ourselves from our lives and fully plunge into the world of the work. 

The people that work with me are all very dedicated to this project, taking time off their work, off their lives. Since I cannot yet pay any of them, it is primordial that I provide for all of their expenses (flight, food and shelter). They are giving me so much of their valuable time, it would be unimaginable that they would have to pay for anything. 

For Greta, we are shooting the video in Paris for two weeks this spring. I will need to provide all expenses for her and our light technician. As well as pay for the rental of our shooting location. Amounting in total to about 1000 euros.

For Thor, we will be shooting the photography and the video in Norway for three weeks this summer. I will need to pay for flights, basic expenses for him, our light technician and myself, as well as gasoline for the boat (since we will mainly be shooting at sea). Which will all roughly amount to 1500 euros.


2) The music:

Lottie Bowater is the music composer for the whole Portraits project, and she is completely working for free, giving so much of herself, composing, recording, gathering musicians, paying for the studio sessions out of her own pocket. The song she created for this second portrait is a 10 minute piece, mainly instrumental, it is longer, more complex then the last song and is thus more demanding materially.

Lottie will play the violin, the piano and the accordion parts herself, but we will need to hire a sax player, a cellist, a drummer and a bass player.

60% of the music money will go to our musicians, and 40% will be for the recording / engineer fee.

In total, this will amount to 650 euros.


3) The photography:

I work on 35mm film. In a project where the aim is to render the movement of the most subtle emotional states, being able to capture every lights, colours and shadows is essential, and I find that only 35mm film can provide that level of depth and detail!

I am finished with the Greta photography part, but I need help to be able to shoot Thor's part. I use approximately 30 cans of films, which, with the processing + scanning of the negatives amounts to 550 euros. 



What you get: 

I know that you are bombarded with campaigns like this all the time so we wanted to make your 'reward' for helping out more than a symbolic one.

Me and Lottie figured that the only real, solid perks we could give out were photos (on my part) and music (on hers).

If you choose to put some of your money into this project, you will get a printed photograph of your choice, basically making it as if you were simply buying one of my photos, except the money would not go to my pocket / a gallery but towards funding the whole project. Each print will be traditionally done (i.e in a darkroom).

Or in a similar way, you can purchase some of Lottie's music, the songs she wrote under her stage name Depresstival, or new material she will compose for you, and again, the money acquired from the selling of her work will not go to her pocket / a record label but towards the making of more music!

----------


That's it!

Thank you for you help!

xxx

story:
Short Summary

Hello friends! We are Christina Beck and Shaina Mathews, co-founders of Thespienne, a feminist theatre company. Love Is Merely A Madness is an examination of the theatrical female voice, love, and their intersection. We love love, but often female characters in plays are defined strictly by their romantic love for another person- a false identity, rigid and unfair (as much fun as pining is, we are more than this, duh). Let's explore the depths of feminine experience and, in doing so, rethink what it means to love. We are no longer de Beauvoir's The Woman in Love; she is now an active agent!

Thespienne is...

A haven for female-identifying theatre artists. An examination of new and old plays alike through the female gaze. What do we get to reclaim? What can we create now, right now? An experiment. An attempt at magic. A Radicalization.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • Studio space for auditions, two rehearsals, and one performance. Promotional materials (paint, poster paper, canvas, GLITTER, brushes, etc.), and, as our actors for this first festival are unpaid, funds to be able to take care of them as well as we are able (via coffee, tea, water, snacks etc.)   
  • For your fabulously generous donations, you will receive a cute lil Thespienne sticker! Photos to come!
  • You will also receive a producer credit for Thespienne's inaugural show!

What We Need & What You Get

Studio space for auditions, two rehearsals, and one performance. Promotional materials (paint, poster paper, canvas, GLITTER, brushes, etc.), and, as our actors for this first festival are unpaid, funds to be able to take care of them as well as we are able (via coffee, tea, water, snacks etc.)   
For your fabulously generous donations, you will receive a cute lil Thespienne sticker! Photos to come!
You will also receive a producer credit for Thespienne's inaugural show!

story:
My name is Lisa Reed, and I live with Bipolar Disorder, Type II. 

While some people may view this life-long mental illness as a death sentence, I have learned that seeking and receiving an accurate diagnosis and the right treatment can be a life-saver. It certainly was for me. 

Unfortunately, bipolar disorder remains a foreign enigma to much of America, so I've decided to embark on a creative journey that will hopefully help others suffering from mental illness, as well as help end the widespread stigma related to it. A few numbers to get you started:

The Project

In order to raise awareness about bipolar disorder and fight the stigma that affects millions of Americans, I'm publishing an art book and launching and 28-day blog called "The Bipolar Alphabet." 

The art book, titledThe Bipolar Alphabet Picture Book, is based on the blog. It will include 26 hand-painted illustrations and a few pages of photos from my life and loved ones who have supported me. Each illustration will have accompanying text in the form of couplets. Think "A is for anxiety that eats at your brain. It tells you to hide, 'You should be afraid.'" (SPOILER: Not every page will be about eating brains. I'm not that much of a zombie fanatic!)

The blog itself is going up every weekday from Tuesday, May 3rd through Thursday, June 9th. There will be one post for each letter of the alphabet, with the exception of the first and last day. In the blog I am also sharing photos from my life and narrative commentary that gives readers an intimate look into the inner workings of a person with this mood disorder. I'm including a few mini-interviews from friends and family to get perspectives from people who've witnessed (and been affected by) my mental illness first-hand.


What We Need & What You Get

As a backer, your money will go toward publishing the book, promotional costs, as well as necessary art supplies and living expenses during the time I'm managing the blog and associated social accounts as a full-time job.

 Expense breakout:

  1. Publishing costs: $6,500
  2. Reward fulfillment: $2,000
  3. Art supply cost: $300
  4. Living expenses while writing and running the blog: $1,200

The money will also go toward creating awesome rewards for backers to choose from: 

Why Should You Invest In This Project?

  • As someone with bipolar disorder, I can truly speak to the cause with my personal story.
  • Bipolar disorder is a topic that's widely misunderstood, which is why an awareness campaign is crucial. We need to change the way people discuss mental health, and encourage a culture that embraces people with mental illness, rather than disregarding them.
  • From 2010 through 2015 I directed social media for two nationally-recognized advocacy organizations in DC, so I have lots of experience in running and delivering on digital campaigns that make an impact.  

Risks & Challenges

While there is always a chance of a major bipolar episode, given my current lifestyle and consistent treatment, the likelihood of that is extremely small. I will also have the help of my dear husband Ian, if necessary.

Since I will be self-publishing, there should by minimal delays with the book going to print.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, sharing my Indiegogo campaign through social media and email would mean so much to me!

Unfortunately, bipolar disorder remains a foreign enigma to much of America, so I've decided to embark on a creative journey that will hopefully help others suffering from mental illness, as well as help end the widespread stigma related to it. A few numbers to get you started:



   The Project
In order to raise awareness about bipolar disorder and fight the stigma that affects millions of Americans, I'm publishing an art book and launching and 28-day blog called "The Bipolar Alphabet." 

The art book, titledThe Bipolar Alphabet Picture Book, is based on the blog. It will include 26 hand-painted illustrations and a few pages of photos from my life and loved ones who have supported me. Each illustration will have accompanying text in the form of couplets. Think "A is for anxiety that eats at your brain. It tells you to hide, 'You should be afraid.'" (SPOILER: Not every page will be about eating brains. I'm not that much of a zombie fanatic!)



The blog itself is going up every weekday from Tuesday, May 3rd through Thursday, June 9th. There will be one post for each letter of the alphabet, with the exception of the first and last day. In the blog I am also sharing photos from my life and narrative commentary that gives readers an intimate look into the inner workings of a person with this mood disorder. I'm including a few mini-interviews from friends and family to get perspectives from people who've witnessed (and been affected by) my mental illness first-hand.


What We Need & What You Get 

As a backer, your money will go toward publishing the book, promotional costs, as well as necessary art supplies and living expenses during the time I'm managing the blog and associated social accounts as a full-time job.
 Expense breakout:


Publishing costs: $6,500
Reward fulfillment: $2,000
Art supply cost: $300
Living expenses while writing and running the blog: $1,200

The money will also go toward creating awesome rewards for backers to choose from: 

   Why Should You Invest In This Project?


As someone with bipolar disorder, I can truly speak to the cause with my personal story.

Bipolar disorder is a topic that's widely misunderstood, which is why an awareness campaign is crucial. We need to change the way people discuss mental health, and encourage a culture that embraces people with mental illness, rather than disregarding them.
From 2010 through 2015 I directed social media for two nationally-recognized advocacy organizations in DC, so I have lots of experience in running and delivering on digital campaigns that make an impact.  
    Risks & Challenges  
While there is always a chance of a major bipolar episode, given my current lifestyle and consistent treatment, the likelihood of that is extremely small. I will also have the help of my dear husband Ian, if necessary.
Since I will be self-publishing, there should by minimal delays with the book going to print.   Other Ways You Can Help Even if you can't contribute financially, sharing my Indiegogo campaign through social media and email would mean so much to me!

story:
I guess I am  happiest when I'm out walking my dogs. And Stanmer Park is one of my favourite places. I have chosen a spot in Stanmer with a view of the house from the woods, and that is the place for my 50th birthday bench. If you contribute it will cost me less, and it will save the wrapping paper. Which means more trees to chop down to make benches. 

I might sew some wild flowers seeds, or leave messages underneath it. I just thought it was a nice idea as most bench dedications are for dead people, and I get to sit on mine. Once it is there ( probably a little while after my birthday) I will let you know where it is, so you can sit on it too. I hope it will be there in the field opposite Stanmer House. A great place for picnics and cow watching.  And I hope it will be there for many years to come.

story:
UPDATE: Sept. 25th 2014.

Oil Painting on artist quality paper canvas, 16” x 20”. Entitled: Red Bath.

By Isaac Wells, 

Ottawa. Date of completion: September 25th 2014.

This painting will be exhibited tomorrow at a special presentation on Animal Rights and Conservation.

This painting corresponds to Perk number 14 and it is also being offered as a reward for those contributing with USD$ 550,oo.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello Everyone!

I am Isaac Wells, a Representational Fine Artist Painter & Photographer, and this is my Indiegogo Campaign for my Oil Paint Supplies.

Through your invaluable and necessary contribution I will be able to buy Oil Paint in tubes of 150ml that I currently need as well as some brushes to keep working on my painting projects.

Here is an example of what I do as a Photographer as well as an Artist Painter.

Cow at the steps of Pico Volcano, 5 feet x 4 feet, Photograph by Isaac Wells, Azores Islands, June 2012.

Cow, by Isaac Wells, oil on canvas, 7 feet x 6 feet; Ottawa, 2013.

Isaac Wells priming the surface for work.

The Studio.

MY MISSION:

My goal on this campaign is to raise USD$ 2124.oo that will be significantly useful to consolidate my art-work production.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
BUDGET:
The funds raised, thanks to your invaluable support, will be indispensible to purchase all supplies that I am currently in need.
Mediums (cans of refined linseed oil, refined stand oil, chemical accelerators, gesso and oil paint ground, rabbit skin glue, solvents and varnish); five free style large brushes of different measurements, and other smaller size brushes; tubes of oil paint colour of 150ml each, all for the amount of USD$ 2124,oo.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PERKS:

In return to your invaluable support, once the campaign has reached its deadline and the funds collected have been forwarded to my account, all rewarded Items will be shipped out to you according to the estimated delivery dates announced on the Perks section. Refer to the perks section for more detailed information.

In terms of editions and prints, contributors will be rewarded with originals, high quality items displaying a minimized copyright attribution. In certain cases some of these items will be signed and limited in numbers. 

Find below the list enunciating and describing each reward:

1-Contributions of USD$ 10,oo. will be rewarded with a especial THANK YOU that will be displayed with your full name on my website, Facebook Art Page, as well as during the Opening evening of the Exhibition.

Refer to the Gallery section of this campaign in order to select the image of your choice.

2-Contributions of USD$ 25,oo. will be rewarded with one high quality 8 x 12 inches print.

3-Contributions of USD$ 40,oo. will be rewarded with two high quality 8 x 12 inches prints.

4-Contributions of USD$ 60,oo will be rewarded with three high quality 8 x 12 inches prints.

5-Contributions of USD$ 80,oo will be rewarded with one 9 inches wide x 7.5 inches high mouse pad, portraying one image of your choice; refer to the Gallery section of this campaign.

6-Contributions of USD$ 100,oo. will be rewarded with one high quality, signed and limited edition print of 11 x 14 inches.

7-Contributions of USD$ 125,oo. will be rewarded with one high quality, signed and limited edition, print of 16 x 20 inches.

8-Contributions of USD$ 175.oo. will be rewarded with one high quality, signed and limited edition, panoramic print of 12 x 36 inches.

9-Contributions of USD$ 200,oo. will be rewarded with an oil painting, single subject, monochrome style, on paper canvas of 16” x 12”. This item can be shipped to you fifteen days after completion to allow proper drying out time and secure packaging. If the contributor is located outside of the artist hometown, the details concerning the piece will be dealt with over the phone and by email exchange. if the contributor is located within the same area as the artist, both will deal with each other in person, by appointment, over the phone and by email exchange. 

Here is an example of a monochrome oil painting on paper canvas of 16” x 12”.

Aunt Aura by Isaac Wells, oil on paper canvas of 16” x 12”; monochrome using Titanium White, Quick Dry White, Ivory Black and Torrit Grey. Ottawa, 21st of September 2014.

10-Contributions of USD$ 250,oo. will be rewarded with one signed and limited edition, high quality, Coffee Table Book (10 editions), hardcover, large landscape of  13 x 11 inches of 50 pages  portraying pictures taken by the Artist -Photographer over four continents.

11-Contributions of USD$ 300,oo. will be rewarded with one signed and limited edition Coffee Table Book (10 editions), hardcover, large landscape of 60 pages of 13 x 11 inches, portraying pictures taken by the Artist -Photographer over four continents.

12-Contributions of USD$ 450,oo. will be rewarded with a private commissioned original portrait, single subject, by Isaac Wells in oil paint, on standard hardboard of 12 x 12 inches, which can only be shipped after 30 days of completion for paint and varnish to have properly dried out. If the contributor is located outside of the artist hometown, the details concerning the piece will be dealt with over the phone and by email exchange. if the contributor is located within the same area as the artist, both will deal with each other in person, by appointment, over the phone and by email exchange.

13-Contributions of USD$ 550,oo. will be rewarded with a private commissioned original portrait, single subject, by Isaac Wells in oil paint, on standard hardboard of 16 x 20 inches, which can only be shipped after 30 days of completion for paint and varnish to have properly dried out. If the contributor is located outside of the artist hometown, the details concerning the piece will be dealt with over the phone and by email exchange. if the contributor is located within the same area as the artist, both will deal with each other in person and by appointment.

Here is a sample of an oil painting of 16”x 20”on wood panel:

Gabriella Wells Portrait; by Isaac Wells. Oil on wood panel, 16” x20”; Ottawa, 2014.
Here is another sample of a 16” x 20” oil painting on canvas.

Gabriella Wells Portrait; by Isaac Wells. Oil on canvas, 16” x20”; Ottawa, 2014.
Here is another example of an oil painting, on Artist Quality paper Canvas of 16” x 20”, single subject.

Cow. Oil on Paper Canvas, by Isaac Wells, Ottawa, September 25th 2014.

14-Contributions of USD$ 650,oo. will be rewarded with the Original Silver Point Drawing on hardboard 18 x 14 inches, by Isaac Wells after Guido Remi, depicting martyr Saint Sebastian shot by arrows, dated 2010.

15-Contributions of USD$ 1000.oo will be rewarded with one original, signed by Isaac Wells, high quality metallic paper, panoramic print of 30 x 72 inches.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MY STORY:

Isaac Wells, Representational Artist Painter & Travel Photographer.

Mural. Oil on wall, using fresco techniques; Clock Tower at Prague; by Isaac Wells, Montreal 2005.

My sister Maria; Drawing; by Isaac Wells. Mixed Media on Paper, 2010.

Flowers, by Isaac Wells. Oil on canvas, 4 feet x 6 feet; Ottawa, 2011. Showroom Exhibit.

<<  ... Susie in the Sky with Flowers ... >> by Isaac Wells. Oil on canvas, 3 feet x 6 feet; Ottawa, 2011. Showroom Exhibit.

This work has been the result of a long-lasting inspiration and profound admiration for Jenny Saville ‘s qualities as a magnificent painter as well as for her work. I replaced the face of her subject by my face using a photo dating back to my childhood. It depicts the face of a burnt child.  Child. By Isaac Wells, Oil on canvas; Ottawa, 2013. At my Studio. 

Isaac Wells, Travel Photographer. Valley of the Kings, West bank, Luxor; September 2013. Egypt in Times of Turmoil.

Photograph of the London Bridge (Andy Warhol style) by Isaac Wells; London, UK, November 2011.


Isaac Wells

Artist Painter & Travel Photographer

Isaac Wells Facebook Art Page

My Website

story:
About nomadMVMT:

Logan Scharadin is the Artistic Director and choreographer of the artist collective known as nomadMVMT, which was founded in New York City in 2013. Their main objective is to bring like-minded artists and creators together with the intention of producing new and innovative work involving a boundless variety of art forms and mediums. Some of the artists involved in the collective are dancers, musicians, painters, costume designers, lighting artists, etc.

Logan Scharadin graduated with a BFA from SUNY Purchase in dance performance. While she was in school she was awarded the opportunity to study abroad at the Beijing Dance Academy where she specialized in choreography. Though she has always had an interest in choreography, she recently became fixated on the need to marry dance performance with other art forms. She started nomadMVMT to connect dance performance with other artists who have a passion for collaborative work. 


This project:

nomadMVMT's first creation has been awarded the opportunity to be a part of this years Wave Rising Series, a dance festival located at the John Ryan Theater under the direction of Young Soon Kim. Logan was also accepted into the Rising Choreographer Residency Program which gives her potentially 50 hours of rehearsal space in the theater where it will be premiered. The festival's goal is to help young artists be seen as well as put on a production in New York City for a reasonable price.

This piece has also been accepted into the Fieldwork program, a new residency that is only offered to Purchase Alumni through Chez Bushwick Inc and the Center for Performance Research. Logan received 15 hours of free rehearsal space through the Chez Bushwick residency and will be performing her newest work along side three other Purchase Alumni at CPR in November. 


Why we need your help:

Since this is a multi-media live performance there are a lot of expenses in addition to the dance aspect. As a director I want to be able to provide the money necessary to make this work. One of the main parts of this piece is the extensive LED light grid that fills the stage and moves along side the performers. Another huge part of this piece is the custom made gown that the 'goddess' is wearing. The gown is made of sheer fabric with a graphic print hand-drawn by artist Adam Bohemond, and sculpted by fashion designer Anthony Argentina. Adam is also hand painting each dancer to fit the character that they portray in the piece. 


Funding:

$400- production fee

$300- rehearsal space (high-demand times when the whole cast is able to make it)

$300- LED tube lights: used to make up the grid structure

$500- all costumes: including one handmade gown by Anthony Argentina with a graphic print by Adam Bohemond

$100- body paint: hand done by Adam Bohemond

$250- advertising

$450- bare minimum pay for all artists involved (composer, dancers, visual artists, costume designer, light artist)

$200- Miscellaneous expenses (such as travel)


All extra money donated will be used to help fund nomadMVMT's future endeavors, such as going on tour with live music!

One of the guiding principles of nomadMVMT is to bring their art outside of the proscenium stage in order to reach out to an audience that would otherwise not be exposed to dance performance. After the premiere of their first work they hope to take to the road and share their art with new audiences in the fashion of a true modern nomad.

But it all starts here and now with you! We need your help! But don't worry we've got some awesome gifts for you if you help make our dreams come true...

story:
Are you tired of accepting Cookies too?

How about we just get rid of cookies? Let's eat that kind of stuff and Go Diafco! 

I guess it's up to the individual consumer to what extent they will be monitored online. All companies with a website need to earn the consumers' trust in order for them to allow the monitoring of their activities on the companies website. 

When companies behave well and wish to interact with the consumers, the consumers will also allow monitoring if the website is interesting enough for them. 

Yes! It's all about profit or attention on the web - but we scare consumers away with all those cookies and especially policies around them. In the EU it's completely crazy with the cookie policy and every time you visit a website with a cookie you must accept it to continue. 

In 1997 I invented a shortcut program to the internet which have been shown to be extremely interesting as a substitute for cookies and now I have developed ver. 2 - you can see more details on our website - and about me here.

What We Need & What You Get

Back in 1997 the software was only made for Win95 and for now we are beta testing the new version for WinXP, WinVista, Win7 and Win8 but our software has to work on all devices/operating systems which means that we are in need of funds for our programmers, approximately $ 50,000.

If you contribute to our project you will get our software to use on your website as described on our Product page and in our Perks.

If we do not reach our goal we will still use all the contributed funds to developing our software and if we get more funds than we need for programming the rest will go to our marketing budget.

The Impact

Our mission is to replace Cookies and let the users Go Diafco!

Back in 1998 i sold copies of the program to companis like LEGO, Copenhagen Stock Exchange and Lollands Bank. The program was even up for consideration as a part of the secure payment solution the authorities in Denmark were working on back then.

However, the collapse of the dotcom bubble in 2001 brought an end to the project.

Risks & Challenges

All new projects involves risks! In my previous project that has been running for 4 years, I forecast that a political change of the government in Denmark was the biggest threat to the project, I even made ​​a SWOT analysis in my business plan with this threat - and indeed the new political constellation changed the rules - just check out the change of the rules on product placement in Denmark since 2010.

So no! I will not write anything about the risk here... In order of "what you fear, you attract!" 

But you can make up your own calculations - there are more than 1 billion websites world wide, and counting, of which 25% are active. Surely there is a market.

Our first challenge is to make the program work on all platforms and server operating systems - regardless of the users preferences.

Our second challenge is to market the program and here we will provide it free of charge to non-profit organizations. Furthermore we have established an affiliated network to boost the sale.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help us in our project and in order of priority: 

Programmers with courage on a split deal - send us an email - go.diafco@gmail.com 

Beta Testers - Sign up here for FREE. 

Tell ALL your friends about the project with the Indiegogo share tools!

Join our JV Partner Program for FREE. 

Like and Share our page and posts on Facebook 

Follow and retweet us on Twitter

Check out our vides and comment them on YouTube

In my previous project that has been running for 4 years, I forecast that a political change of the government in Denmark was the biggest threat to the project, I even made ​​a SWOT analysis in my business plan with this threat - and indeed the new political constellation changed the rules - just check out the change of the rules on product placement in Denmark since 2010.

So no! I will not write anything about the risk here... In order of "what you fear, you attract!" 
But you can make up your own calculations - there are more than 1 billion websites world wide, and counting, of which 25% are active. Surely there is a market.
Our first challenge is to make the program work on all platforms and server operating systems - regardless of the users preferences.
Our second challenge is to market the program and here we will provide it free of charge to non-profit organizations. Furthermore we have established an affiliated network to boost the sale.
Other Ways You Can Help
 
There are many ways you can help us in our project and in order of priority: 
Programmers with courage on a split deal - send us an email - go.diafco@gmail.com 
Beta Testers - Sign up here for FREE. 
Tell ALL your friends about the project with the Indiegogo share tools!
Join our JV Partner Program for FREE. 
Like and Share our page and posts on Facebook 
Follow and retweet us on Twitter
Check out our vides and comment them on YouTube

story:
Short Summary

I Started the Fire is a short character study about internal struggle and transition. A young woman is accused of setting a deadly fire in her home town. To avoid punishment for a fire she believes she did not set, she flees to the woods, building her camp around an abandoned car hidden in a clearing. With this new found isolation, freedom and need to survive,  the young woman uncovers her true relationship with fire, and struggles to control it. 

ABOUT THE CAST AND CREW 

CECILY BROWN, DIRECTOR

I Started the Fire is a thesis film written and directed by Cecily Brown, a film and photography student at Ithaca College. During her years in school, Cecily has spent her time working on a variety of film and photography projects,  ranging from television, documentary, experimental and commercial. Her education has led up to this project and she cannot wait to start shooting! You can see more of her previous work on these sites: Film Projects & Photography

SAM MANK, PRODUCER 

Sam Mank has been involved in many professional film and television projects in the NYC area. His experience ranges from Locations and Talent coordination to Post Production Sound Mixing and Color Grading. Having lived in Maine previously he will be handling all logistics in dealing with locations, fire permits, travel and a host of other production needs. 

SHANE RUBANO, CINEMATOGRAPHER

Shane Rubano is a working professional camera operator and Director of Photography. Graduating from Ithaca College last spring, he has pursued his dream of crafting images on the professional, indie, and commercial circuit. You can view some of his work here: www.shanerubano.com 

FIORELLA FERNANDEZ, LEAD

Fiorella Fernandez is an acting major at Ithaca College. Fiorella was most recently seen on stage as Hodel in Fiddler on the Roof, Olive Ostrovsky in Spelling Bee, and Natalie Goodman in Next to Normal with various theatre companies. She is stoked to be able to have the opportunity to tell this fascinating story and be able to undertake such an exciting challenge. 

Not only is the completion of a thesis film required to graduate, but  also the culmination of four years of intense and rigorous work in film production and studies. As graduation rapidly approaches we hope to create a work that we are proud of and one that will function as a testament to our skill sets for our future careers. In order to make this film we need the help of those who care about  young artists and film!

What We Need & What You Get

We will be shooting the film in beautiful mid-coastal Maine over the course of 10 days. We have a small crew of talented filmmakers and artists collaborating to bring this project onto the screen, however shooting a film is an expensive endeavor. We can't do it without some help! 
Covering the cost of food, housing and travel for the cast and crew is always one of the most expensive aspects of making a film. Such talented and hardworking people deserve three good meals and a bed to sleep on at the end of each day of production! Not to mention any reimbursements in gas or travel costs. 
This film, despite it being set in the middle of the woods, will rely heavily on props, set dressing and production design. Furnishing a car and a campsite, as well as costumes and sfx makeup for our actress, are very important to the overall look and feel of the film. These aspects are vital in convincing an audience of the world and story we are establishing. To get the right style and period we will need very specific props and set dressings, which often add up very quickly. 
Throughout the script there are many instances of fire. It is our top priority to use fire in the safest, most practical and manageable ways throughout the course of production. Purchasing enough safety equipment, consulting local officials and gathering the correct burn permits are extremely important in creating a safe environment on set in order to accomplish our goals. 
The cost of post-production color grading and sound mixing, as well as film festival fees, DVD manufacturing and promotional materials are yet another aspect of our process that we will be completing with your help. 
By donating you will receive promotional materials, a copy of the project, credit in the film for your help, and many other cool things! For more information about the perks look over to your left! 
If we don't reach the final goal of $3,500 we will still receive a portion of what we raised, however IndieGogo will take a larger percentage for the use of this platform. Please help us raise the entire $3,500! 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't spare some change or any amount of money to help us reach our goal, please consider sharing this page with your friends and family and those who you think might be interested! Even if you donate, sharing the link will help us reach a wider audience! 

    We will post updates on this page over the course of the entire project so please come back and visit!

story:
With your donations, we'll convert our backyard into an outdoor art studio, equipped with mediums of all kinds and canvases of all sizes (the more you give, the crazier supplies we'll get). In the daylight hours, come chill out and create. At night we'll retreat and resume festivities inside.

We encourage you to bring a black or white shirt to record the experience. We will proudly keep and display any of the art created throughout the house, but feel free to take what you make. Anything left over will decorate the walls Bob Schmitz has so greyed. (Any supplies left over we'll give to the Durham School of the Arts).

See the Facebook event for more details. If you would like to invite a friend we don't know, message us! We'll add them to the event. And though drinks will be served, your artisan beer, fancy boxed wine, and first class liquor is always welcome.

story:
***GOAL HAS BEEN REACHED*** thanks to the donations here, and some generous off-line and air miles donations, my goal was reached in a little over 24hours!***

about me, my work, and why i need to get to ARTSCAPE

i am queer and gender queer, feminist erotic film maker from the Canadian prairies. i create and collaborate on the production of consensual, ethically produced pornography and performative sex education that is reflective and celebratory of a diverse array of sexualities, bodies, genders, acts and partnerships.

queer, feminist pornography has been a major piece of my coming to understand and accept my own sexuality, gender and kinks as being 100%, completely healthy - i would even go so far as to say it has saved my life. 

with the majority of the work i do, i am behind the camera. this puts me in a position of power, which means it is my responsibility to actively challenge and deconstruct this dynamic that so often gets exploited in mainstream pornography and sex work. it is also my responsibility to challenge the power dynamics and structures that come with the privileges i benefit from as a white, able-bodied settler, doing this work on First Nations' land.

being able to attend the ARTSCAPE feminist artist in residency program will give me the  rare opportunity to explore this process on a deeper, more critical level with the direction and wisdom from leaders in both the feminist and arts communities. 

i believe that intentional practices and explorations such as what this ARTSCAPE program offers, fosters consent culture both in and out of the industry, invites us to let go of shame and stigma around pornography and our own sexualities and desires, and will allow me to take my art and activism in a direction that has the potential to open many doors for those in the communities i am a part of.

What is ARTSCAPE and what's the deal with this feminist artist in residence?

ARTSCAPE is a not-for-profit urban development organization that makes space for creativity and transforms communities. the particular off-shoot of this program i will be attending is one of their programmed residencies, which allow artists to work independently with the mentorship of a visiting professional artist working in international contemporary art. 

the particular programmed residence i have been accepted into, is one being facilitated by the founder of the Feminist Arts Conference (FAC), Ilene Sova. Sova is a conceptual portrait painter who creates paintings which reference anti-oppression feminist themes, and during this two-week program, we will focus on social justice issues such as rape culture, trans phobia, racism, violence, media representation, cultural appropriation, environmental degradation and impact on Aboriginal lands, violence against women, and Islamophobic policies. 

the residency will include individual studio time accented with group discussions, readings, video, reflection, guest speakers, group and individual critiques, and i my resulting work will be presented in an exhibition at the end of the residency and pending curatorial acceptance, may be included in a spotlight exhibition at FAC 2015.


FAC art residency is limited to 20 residents of multidisciplinary artists (literature, visual arts, theatre, spoken word, music, visual arts, and film) - i have been chosen as one of those 20! 

***GOAL HAS BEEN REACHED*** thanks to the donations here, and some generous off-line and air miles donations, my goal was reached in a little over 24hours!***
 what i need $1500 for

tuition to the Feminist Art Conference ARTSCAPE program is $750

airfare from Edmonton - Toronto = currently $600-$650  

airfare has been covered by a very generous donation of air miles!
