story:
About the Littlest Finch & Sticks and Stones Studio!

Hello Friends! I am an independent artist out of the PNW known as Finch! Recently, in October of 2017, I opened an Etsy shop under the name Sticks and Stones Studio! The plan was to create a shop catering to all the folk out there who share my fascination with the beauty, the magic and the strangeness of the natural world through stickers! I was not quite expecting my little shop to do as well as it has, and although I feel positively blessed, I did not quite think through the extent of the labors associated with my shop!

As a human adult, definitely not a goblin, I do have a full time job that eats away the majority of my day time hours and then some. This does not leave a lot of time to create a lot of art, let alone print, cut, pack and send said art. What has started to happen now is that I'm spending more time cutting out stickers for orders than I am able to spend creating new designs! When I first opened the shop my plan was to offer bi-weekly sticker updates packed full of new designs for both new packs and existing packs! Unfortunately because of my job and the consistent influx of orders, I've been totally unable to find the time!

So I decided to do some research into ways I can automate my process a little further! Research showed me the Cricut Explore Air 2 as the perfect solution to my problem! Not only will this handy machine cut out stickers, but it will also allow me to create sticker sheets! So it would both ease my process and help me expand what I'm able to offer! This would be an absolutely huge boost to my business and my ability to expand as a content creator!

 

What does your money go towards?

I'm asking for a little more money than the actual cost of the machine so here is a break down on what that is for! I decided now was a great time to expand not just my automation abilities, but several other awesome things, such as vinyl stickers and holographic stickers! Your money will help towards building these goals.

-Cricut Explore Air 2 270$ + Shipping

-Ink for my printer! I plan to purchase approximately 2x box with CYMK 40$ 2x boxes with CYM 24$ each. Total: 128$

-Laminator for applying holographic tape and protective sheeting for more waterproof stickers 30$

-100 sheets matte vinyl sticker paper 50$ + Shipping

-1 30ft x 6inch roll of holographic transfer film 30$

-1 pack of 100 laminate sleeves 13$

-100$ for site fees, shipping fees and shipping supplies for perks!

 

The Impact

I absolutely can't stress enough how this will not only be a quality of life improvement for me, but also will allow me to truly expand what I'm able to offer! Being able to fund like this will allow me to keep my prices low, rather than having them reflect in the cost of such a big investment!

Pricing aside this will allow me to continue to ship products quickly, as I currently try to get orders out within two business days. It will also allow me to focus more on the packing of my orders which I always put the most love possible into!

More time not only means better orders but time to focus on bi-weekly updates for my shop. New products I have planned such as my Crystal Oracle Deck will find time to be worked on. It will also allow me to save money for a printer upgrade so I can provide better prints as well! This investment will not only benefit my shop but my customer base as well!

 

Final Notes & Other Ways to Help!~

Even if I hit 1/3 of my proposed funding it will be hugely helpful! If you can't spare money I 100% understand but would totally appreciate if you shared my campaign just so my shop continues to receive some visibility.

Spreading a little love through my art and stickers honestly brings me so much joy! It's one of those wonderful broke artist dreams and you guys are really helping me to achieve them. From the bottom of my heart thank you!

Places you can find me!

Tumblr: @sticksandstones-studio

Instagram: @Littlestfinchart

Etsy: @SticksandStonesStudio

 

PS for Backers & Perks!

If you back a perk that has sticker packs you can pick any pack currently available in my shop, please e-mail me at littlestfinchart@gmail.com, ask me via Indiegogo or reach out to me on IG/Tumblr about what packs you want specifically!

I will be reaching out to my beautiful sticker collaborators through e-mail, so I'll try to reach out to everyone who gets packs to confirm your orders before shipping. Otherwise I will just send you a ton of random sticker love!
story_txt:
About the Littlest Finch & Sticks and Stones Studio!
Hello Friends! I am an independent artist out of the PNW known as Finch! Recently, in October of 2017, I opened an Etsy shop under the name Sticks and Stones Studio! The plan was to create a shop catering to all the folk out there who share my fascination with the beauty, the magic and the strangeness of the natural world through stickers! I was not quite expecting my little shop to do as well as it has, and although I feel positively blessed, I did not quite think through the extent of the labors associated with my shop!
As a human adult, definitely not a goblin, I do have a full time job that eats away the majority of my day time hours and then some. This does not leave a lot of time to create a lot of art, let alone print, cut, pack and send said art. What has started to happen now is that I'm spending more time cutting out stickers for orders than I am able to spend creating new designs! When I first opened the shop my plan was to offer bi-weekly sticker updates packed full of new designs for both new packs and existing packs! Unfortunately because of my job and the consistent influx of orders, I've been totally unable to find the time!
So I decided to do some research into ways I can automate my process a little further! Research showed me the Cricut Explore Air 2 as the perfect solution to my problem! Not only will this handy machine cut out stickers, but it will also allow me to create sticker sheets! So it would both ease my process and help me expand what I'm able to offer! This would be an absolutely huge boost to my business and my ability to expand as a content creator!
 

What does your money go towards?
I'm asking for a little more money than the actual cost of the machine so here is a break down on what that is for! I decided now was a great time to expand not just my automation abilities, but several other awesome things, such as vinyl stickers and holographic stickers! Your money will help towards building these goals.
-Cricut Explore Air 2 270$ + Shipping
-Ink for my printer! I plan to purchase approximately 2x box with CYMK 40$ 2x boxes with CYM 24$ each. Total: 128$
-Laminator for applying holographic tape and protective sheeting for more waterproof stickers 30$
-100 sheets matte vinyl sticker paper 50$ + Shipping
-1 30ft x 6inch roll of holographic transfer film 30$
-1 pack of 100 laminate sleeves 13$
-100$ for site fees, shipping fees and shipping supplies for perks!
 

The Impact
I absolutely can't stress enough how this will not only be a quality of life improvement for me, but also will allow me to truly expand what I'm able to offer! Being able to fund like this will allow me to keep my prices low, rather than having them reflect in the cost of such a big investment!
Pricing aside this will allow me to continue to ship products quickly, as I currently try to get orders out within two business days. It will also allow me to focus more on the packing of my orders which I always put the most love possible into!
More time not only means better orders but time to focus on bi-weekly updates for my shop. New products I have planned such as my Crystal Oracle Deck will find time to be worked on. It will also allow me to save money for a printer upgrade so I can provide better prints as well! This investment will not only benefit my shop but my customer base as well!
 
Final Notes & Other Ways to Help!~
Even if I hit 1/3 of my proposed funding it will be hugely helpful! If you can't spare money I 100% understand but would totally appreciate if you shared my campaign just so my shop continues to receive some visibility.
Spreading a little love through my art and stickers honestly brings me so much joy! It's one of those wonderful broke artist dreams and you guys are really helping me to achieve them. From the bottom of my heart thank you!
Places you can find me!
Tumblr: @sticksandstones-studio
Instagram: @Littlestfinchart
Etsy: @SticksandStonesStudio
 
PS for Backers & Perks!
If you back a perk that has sticker packs you can pick any pack currently available in my shop, please e-mail me at littlestfinchart@gmail.com, ask me via Indiegogo or reach out to me on IG/Tumblr about what packs you want specifically! 
I will be reaching out to my beautiful sticker collaborators through e-mail, so I'll try to reach out to everyone who gets packs to confirm your orders before shipping. Otherwise I will just send you a ton of random sticker love!

story:
Me and My Exhibition

  • My name is Sian.  I'm an illustration student from Milton Keynes, which is a town 50 miles from London, UK.  I'm fascinated by history and my degree was in Art History.
  • I've been offered a one-week solo exhibition at Milton Keynes Gallery, as part of their scheme Project Space 2012.  I'll be contributing a series of drawings, paintings and prints, illustrating scenes I've read about in local history books, and quotes by codebreakers, Land Girls and evacuees.
  • I've been a full-time student for a year, which has left me with limited finances.  The Gallery's unable to offer me a grant for this project.  I already own a lot of the raw materials, but I need to find a way to pay for some peripheral things, without which you just can't mount an exhibition.

The Stories I'm Telling

I'm hoping that my research and illustrations can form the basis of one of my MA projects, and perhaps become my first published children's book!

  • Milton Keynes was founded as a new town in 1967, so it's often thought of as very modern place: glass office buildings, a shopping centre and a baffling road system.  But we have ancient ruins, mentions in the Doomsday Book... and we played this extraordinary role in WW2.
  • During WW2, the area of Bletchley was the centre of the Allies' top secret intelligence campaign.  Young people there broke Nazi codes and ciphers, shortening the War by at least two years, saving countless lives.  They weren't allowed to talk about their work until 1977.  In the fields which were later to become MK shops and residential areas, the Women's Land Army took over the agricultural labour which had to be done while male farm workers were off fighting.  And as MK is so inland, it didn't attract many bombs -- so foster families took in children evacuated from the Blitz.
  • At Bletchley Park, it wasn't all tweedy pipe-smoking professors: 3/4 of the staff were women, the average age was 19, they had a drama society and skated on the lake in winter.  People needed to be young, vigorous and passionate to be able to withstand the long hours and the immense pressure of knowing their secret work could make or break Britain's war effort.  The Land Girls weren't all the rosy-cheeked maids of propaganda posters, looking all capable with farm machinery: the girls often had no training and had to do unphotogenic jobs like rat-catching and mucking out pigs.  But they got on with it because they knew feeding the nation was vital -- and they didn't get any official thanks for their efforts until 2007, when all living Land Girls received a commemorative badge.  They were known as 'the Cinderella Service'.  I really want to illustrate the stories of all these unsung heroes, bringing their work to the attention of a new generation.
  • This is a topical project.  2012 is the centenary of the star codebreaker and father of modern computing, Alan Turing.  2012 is also apparently the last year the former Land Girls will be marching past the Cenotaph.

Where the £500 Will Go

  • FRAMES
    At the moment, I'm not able to frame my pictures.  Getting a professional picture-framer to frame my work will be prohibitively expensive, even if I can make a sponsorship deal with them.
    My neighbour kindly donated two big ornate antique frames and I'm going to find a third that will complement them.  There will be three large pictures, surrounded by lots of smaller pictures in plain white Ikea frames.  £8 per frame x 20 = £160.
  • PRINTING
    Some of my work is digital and will need to be printed professionally.  This may cost up to £200. 
  • INTERACTIVE ELEMENTS
    The Gallery are excited to be exhibiting work that will appeal to children.  I thought I could add an interactive element in the corner -- a rug, some cushions, old teddies, books about the War, photos, replica ration books, etc.  (£50? / donations)
  • INDIEGOGO FEES
    If I raise the amount I need, Indiegogo take a 4% slice.  If I don't reach my target, they take 9%.  (Plus a bit more because my bank account is outside the US.)
  • LEFTOVERS: CHARITY DONATIONS
    Any money I have left over, I'll donate to the Bletchley Park Charitable Trust  http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/shop/changeDonate.rhtm/
    or RABI http://landarmy.org.uk/home.html

What This Means to Me

  • I used to live in London and have a job in journalism.  I found my work dull and I felt very frustrated and unchallenged.  Last year, I made the big decision to resign, move back in with my long-suffering parents, and return to education.  I've just completed the Foundation diploma at MK College, which (along with my BA in Art History) gave me the portfolio I needed to get into the MA in Children's Book Illustration at Cambridge School of Art.  I loved every bit of my Foundation, yet I already feel that this summer project is going to be a crash course in how to be a professional artist, not just a student.  I've been dreaming about doing this MA for seven years, and always been too nervous, kept thinking of very practical, very dream-crushing reasons not to do it.  Now it's all ahead of me, I've had great feedback on my creative work so far and I feel like my career is finally getting going.  Being offered this public exhibition was a big confidence boost and I'd really love to do something I can be proud of.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute money, please let others know about my campaign -- maybe you know someone who can! Please RT the link to this page on Twitter, share on Facebook, or mention it on your own little corner of the Internets.
  • If you're quite local / London, please let me know if you have artefacts you could lend to my interactive exhibit. Be aware that you'd be risking theft or sticky fingers (although the Gallery will be insured). But if you have any objects or textiles that would suit a 1940s corner for art-loving children, get in touch.
  • If you have memories of the times I'm illustrating, or know someone who does, and would like to talk to me about your experiences, I would LOVE to hear from you. Please email sian@drawosaur.com
  • And of course, by coming to view the exhibition when it's up!

I used to live in London and have a job in journalism.  I found my work dull and I felt very frustrated and unchallenged.  Last year, I made the big decision to resign, move back in with my long-suffering parents, and return to education.  I've just completed the Foundation diploma at MK College, which (along with my BA in Art History) gave me the portfolio I needed to get into the MA in Children's Book Illustration at Cambridge School of Art.  I loved every bit of my Foundation, yet I already feel that this summer project is going to be a crash course in how to be a professional artist, not just a student.  I've been dreaming about doing this MA for seven years, and always been too nervous, kept thinking of very practical, very dream-crushing reasons not to do it.  Now it's all ahead of me, I've had great feedback on my creative work so far and I feel like my career is finally getting going.  Being offered this public exhibition was a big confidence boost and I'd really love to do something I can be proud of.



Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute money, please let others know about my campaign -- maybe you know someone who can! Please RT the link to this page on Twitter, share on Facebook, or mention it on your own little corner of the Internets.
If you're quite local / London, please let me know if you have artefacts you could lend to my interactive exhibit. Be aware that you'd be risking theft or sticky fingers (although the Gallery will be insured). But if you have any objects or textiles that would suit a 1940s corner for art-loving children, get in touch.
If you have memories of the times I'm illustrating, or know someone who does, and would like to talk to me about your experiences, I would LOVE to hear from you. Please email sian@drawosaur.com
And of course, by coming to view the exhibition when it's up!

story:
Be A Part Of Art History

Iphonic Art, aka iphoneography, iphone photography, or mobile photography, is an exploding underground art movement which has grown into a global phenomenon. P1xels - a world-wide community of artists - has been home to the pioneers of the iphonic art medium since it was launched in December of 2009.

The talent, passion, and discipline evidenced in even the earliest batch of submissions for the first gallery show made it clear to us that we had tapped into something very exciting, special, and, most of all, enduring.

Since the site's inception at pixelsatanexhibition.com almost three years ago, people have simply always referred us as "Pixels." So, with the launch of the new site, we will be moving it to P1xels.com.

P1xels was instrumental in defining the medium itself in these early days: where other sites allowed (and still do) off-device editing, we insisted work be shot with an iPhone, processed solely on the tiny iPhone screen with existing photo apps. In other words, we insisted that the device itself define the medium. 

As Henri Matisse once said, "Much of the beauty that arises in art comes from the struggle an artist wages with his limited medium." 

Matisse's remark is so perfectly appropriate to iphonic art, made on this tiny device, a medium not afraid to pursue beauty, unencumbered, as it were, by modern art/photography theory and dogma.

Iphonic art is something new: just look at the pictures. They will tell you.

P1xels is, indeed, the site of record for the iphonic art movement, a pressure cooker for the rapid evolution of this wonderful new visual form of magical realism. 

“Our fine arts were developed, their types and uses were established, in times very different from the present, by men whose power of action upon things was insignificant in comparison with ours. But the amazing growth of our techniques, the adaptability and precision they have attained, the ideas and habits they are creating, make it a certainty that profound changes are impending in the ancient craft of the Beautiful.” 

                                        —Paul Valéry, Aesthetics

A brief history of P1xels:

  • First and only curated daily iphonic art site, Pixels—The Art of the iPhone.
  • First juried iphonic art gallery show ever (Giorgi 2010). Second juried show, Oakbook 2010. Third juried show, OCCCA 2011. (And others since.)
  • First iphonic art site with its own app.
  • First site/show to be featured in New York Times, in major metro daily (Contra Costa Times/SJ Mercury News/SF News Group), in national/international press (Washington Post), in the Huffington Post, in a major national magazine, The Atlantic Monthly, on the Voice of America broadcast throughout the Middle East. And much more press.
  • First to be invited by Apple to produce iphonic art events in Apple Stores around the country to introduce the medium to the public. (SF, LA, Chicago, NYC)
  • First major interview on Flipboard (Apple App of the Year) as well as inclusion as first and only iPhonic art in featured premium content on Flipboard.
  • First traveling iphonic art show: Orange County Center for Contemporary Art, Santa Ana, Arty Gallery, Los Angeles, Giorgi Gallery, Berkeley (April, June, October) 2011.
  • First iphonic art magazine, P1XELS
  • First large-format print show (Los Angeles Center For Digital Art 2012).
  • First iPhonic art site to begin selling limited edition archival prints.

A overview of exhibitions and events:

  • Pixels At An Exhibition (200 prints)  Giorgi Gallery, Berkeley;  January 30-February 28 2010
  • Iphontography 2010  (44 prints)  The OakBook Gallery,  Jack London Square,  Oakland; May 15-June 13 2010
  • Iphoneography 2010: The Unfolding  (64 prints)  Kahbang Festival,  Bangor,  Maine; August 6-14 2010
  • Apple store events  2010-2011 (invited by Apple):  (25-40 prints, 200+ slides in presentations)  July 8, 2010 (San Francisco - for Artistic Photographers of America presentation);  September 27, 2010  (San Francisco);  October 21, 2010  (Chicago);   October 29, 2010  (New York City);  November 11, 2010  (Santa Monica);   July 25, 2011 (San Francisco);  October 21, 2011  (Santa Monica)
  • Orange County Center For Contemporary Art  (136 images)  March 31 – April 28, 2011
  • Arty Gallery  (144 images)  Los Angeles  June 1 – June 30, 2011
  • Giorgi Gallery  (60 images)  Berkeley Pixels Comes Home To Where It All Began  September 22 – October 30, 2011
  • Los Angeles Center For Digital Art  (38 images)  April 12-May 5, 2012
  • Torpedo Factory Art Center,  Alexandria, Virginia  May 10-May 31 2012
  • More in the works.

P1xels has garnered extensive coverage in the American and International Press, in print, video, and online for these very reasons. 

And an overview of press:

  • Divergent Mediums: Photography vs. iPhoneography, by Michael O’Sullivan of the Washington Post. May 2012.
  • A nice write-up in Hong Kong’s premier lifestyle magazine the Ming Pao Weekly.
  • Nice write-up for the 1% in Mercedes-Benz Magazine of Australia.
  • P1xels is now available as featured content on Flipboard (Apple’s iPad App Of The Year) for iPhone and iPad.
  • Flipboard's "On the Red Couch" interview: Knox Bronson of P1xels at an Exhibition
  • A nice video feature on P1xels at the great site, Electric Playground, published on Thanksgiving Day, 2011.
  • Feature article in the Sydney Morning Herald, August 13, 2011, by Sacha Molitorisz
  • A video feature, broadcast throughout the Middle East on Voice of America in June 2011.
  • A feature by John Seed, art writer for the Huffington Post. 
  • When Cult Of Mac, one of the web’s biggest Apple-centric blogs, wanted a year-end wrap-up, a gallery, and a discussion of the shape of things to come in the world of iphonic art, they came to P1xels, of course.
  • Mashable, the giant social networking and technology site named Pixels the #1 site for iPhone photography on October 30, 2010.
  • The Atlantic Monthly online published a fascinating article on the historical context of iphonic art, comparing it to the pictorialists of the early twentieth century. Both P1xels and P1xels’ artist Maia Panos were singled out.
  • Jennifer Modenessi, who covers the SF Bay Area art and culture beat, has written a wonderful story about “Pixels At An Exhibition”  appearing in several Bay Area papers, the San Jose Mercury News, the Contra Costa Times and the Oakland Tribune.
  • New York Times December 28, 2009 iPhone Photos Become High Art in Gallery Competition - Our first piece of press, the New York Times.  

Our goal:  a beautiful and elegant new user experience for site visitors with increased control and interactivity for artists, and tools to foster creativity within the iphonic art comunity

The next essential step in the journey is a modern, usable, and beautiful user experience that translates across all devices, mobile or not. Built to connect and nurture the growing community of artists and to enhance the enjoyment of the medium by the art-loving public as awareness and appreciation of the art form continues to build.

We have a wonderful new site planned, actually, a whole new user experience, with whatever device visitors use to visit the site, one that also will give our artists much more control over their submissions, as well as increased interaction with each other and the public. Not only that, a new site will free us up to pursue other pressing matters: cultural, institutional, and corporate to develop and promote our artists, their work, and the medium.

There is still much to be done! A new P1xels website is the first step.

P1xels 2.0 website Features

1. Retina display support for iPad, iPhone, and any other Retina-display ready devices.

2. Touch-enabled navigation for mobile devices

  • modern html5 and css3 responsive design (adapts to any size screen)
  • a really cool new navigation interface for exploring our wonderful and huge collection of curated images, as well as galleries, interviews, and articles
  • built-in uploading from iphone/ipad (eventually will support other mobile devices)

3. Improved sharing features for site visitors and artists:

  • facebook
  • twitter
  • pinterest
  • email
  • e-cards
  • ibooks

4. Improved artist features on the site:

  • profile pages
  • artist galleries (P1xels will always remain curated on the front end, but we want artists to have the opportunity to show more of their work)
  • friend list
  • favorites
  • discussion boards/forums
  • submission queue (see what you've submitted, and what has been accepted)


5. Facebook integration for registration & login

6. E-commerce for prints & merchandise

Obviously, a project of this scope requires much design, development, and testing time, which is where contributions will be allocated. As with everything we've done at P1xels from the start, the end goal is bringing beautiful art to the public in the most elegant manner and to give maximum exposure to the pioneering artists who bring forth that beauty.

P1xels 2.0 will be the platform from which we will be able to launch many exciting inititatives.

For Contributors

We have a number of wonderful rewards for you, every single one reflecting the energy and excitement of this emergent art form: stickers, prints, t-shirts, digital downloads, even a cd which has music featured in the video (for the record, Erik Satie is the patron saint of P1xels), a poster ... in all contribution ranges. We hope there is something there for everybody. Something beautiful, special, something enduring.

We will of course add you to our donor list on the site, but only if you wish. And add you to our newsletter list, which goes out every blue moon or so. But probably more often when the new site is launched.

Welcome to the global iphonic art community!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everybody can contribute financially. So we would ask that you please share this campaign with your friends, particularly the art-loving ones, via Facebook, or email, or Twitter, if you do that, or in person or however. We will appreciate your effort.

Also, please visit our site, Pixels—The Art of the iPhone, often. It's free, and wonderful, and we get amazing work from around the world every single day.

A Final Word

Knox here.

This has been an amazing journey. I had no idea what I was getting into when I launched the site way back when. I just wanted to do the Giorgi show and get some of my and Maia Panos's pictures on the gallery wall. No thoughts or plans beyond that. 

But something happened, not anticipated at all: I fell in love with the work that came in. And the artists. And the medium. Maia and I used to sit together and look at the work coming in and just marvel at the rapid evolution of the medium. Everybody was looking at what everybody else was doing (this is still happening) and learning and experimenting and pushing themselves. P1xels was and is the lab, the crucible for the whole movement.

And so it began. Like a runaway train.

We have never sought development money before now, focusing, rather, on the art and the artists. Everything we've done, we've done with virtually no money: passion, stubbornness, and more than a few would say a bit of insanity have been the driving forces behind our accomplishments.

This, I believe without doubt, is what has made P1xels the pre-eminent iphonic art site in the world. But fear not: money will not spoil P1xels; P1xels has been its own crucible for us as well. We know where we are going.

Almost three years down the road, I still believe iphonic art to be the most vibrant and exciting new art medium on the planet. I ask you to be a part of it. It is still a young art form. Many fine artists have emerged; none are household names. Yet. It remains our mission to continue bringing forth and promoting these pioneering artists and their work.

Please join us.

Thank you.

 (For links to all P1xels Media Coverage, you may click here.)

When Cult Of Mac, one of the web’s biggest Apple-centric blogs, wanted a year-end wrap-up, a gallery, and a discussion of the shape of things to come in the world of iphonic art, they came to P1xels, of course.

Mashable, the giant social networking and technology site named Pixels the #1 site for iPhone photography on October 30, 2010.
The Atlantic Monthly online published a fascinating article on the historical context of iphonic art, comparing it to the pictorialists of the early twentieth century. Both P1xels and P1xels’ artist Maia Panos were singled out. 

Jennifer Modenessi, who covers the SF Bay Area art and culture beat, has written a wonderful story about “Pixels At An Exhibition”  appearing in several Bay Area papers, the San Jose Mercury News, the Contra Costa Times and the Oakland Tribune.


New York Times December 28, 2009 iPhone Photos Become High Art in Gallery Competition - Our first piece of press, the New York Times.  

Our goal:  a beautiful and elegant new user experience for site visitors with increased control and interactivity for artists, and tools to foster creativity within the iphonic art comunity
The next essential step in the journey is a modern, usable, and beautiful user experience that translates across all devices, mobile or not. Built to connect and nurture the growing community of artists and to enhance the enjoyment of the medium by the art-loving public as awareness and appreciation of the art form continues to build.
We have a wonderful new site planned, actually, a whole new user experience, with whatever device visitors use to visit the site, one that also will give our artists much more control over their submissions, as well as increased interaction with each other and the public. Not only that, a new site will free us up to pursue other pressing matters: cultural, institutional, and corporate to develop and promote our artists, their work, and the medium.
There is still much to be done! A new P1xels website is the first step.
P1xels 2.0 website Features
1. Retina display support for iPad, iPhone, and any other Retina-display ready devices.
2. Touch-enabled navigation for mobile devices

modern html5 and css3 responsive design (adapts to any size screen)
a really cool new navigation interface for exploring our wonderful and huge collection of curated images, as well as galleries, interviews, and articles
built-in uploading from iphone/ipad (eventually will support other mobile devices)

3. Improved sharing features for site visitors and artists:

facebook
twitter
pinterest
email
e-cards
ibooks

4. Improved artist features on the site:

profile pages
artist galleries (P1xels will always remain curated on the front end, but we want artists to have the opportunity to show more of their work)
friend list
favorites
discussion boards/forums
submission queue (see what you've submitted, and what has been accepted)

5. Facebook integration for registration & login6. E-commerce for prints & merchandise
Obviously, a project of this scope requires much design, development, and testing time, which is where contributions will be allocated. As with everything we've done at P1xels from the start, the end goal is bringing beautiful art to the public in the most elegant manner and to give maximum exposure to the pioneering artists who bring forth that beauty.
P1xels 2.0 will be the platform from which we will be able to launch many exciting inititatives.
For Contributors
We have a number of wonderful rewards for you, every single one reflecting the energy and excitement of this emergent art form: stickers, prints, t-shirts, digital downloads, even a cd which has music featured in the video (for the record, Erik Satie is the patron saint of P1xels), a poster ... in all contribution ranges. We hope there is something there for everybody. Something beautiful, special, something enduring.
We will of course add you to our donor list on the site, but only if you wish. And add you to our newsletter list, which goes out every blue moon or so. But probably more often when the new site is launched.
Welcome to the global iphonic art community!
Other Ways You Can Help
We know that not everybody can contribute financially. So we would ask that you please share this campaign with your friends, particularly the art-loving ones, via Facebook, or email, or Twitter, if you do that, or in person or however. We will appreciate your effort.
Also, please visit our site, Pixels—The Art of the iPhone, often. It's free, and wonderful, and we get amazing work from around the world every single day.
A Final Word
Knox here.
This has been an amazing journey. I had no idea what I was getting into when I launched the site way back when. I just wanted to do the Giorgi show and get some of my and Maia Panos's pictures on the gallery wall. No thoughts or plans beyond that. 
But something happened, not anticipated at all: I fell in love with the work that came in. And the artists. And the medium. Maia and I used to sit together and look at the work coming in and just marvel at the rapid evolution of the medium. Everybody was looking at what everybody else was doing (this is still happening) and learning and experimenting and pushing themselves. P1xels was and is the lab, the crucible for the whole movement.
And so it began. Like a runaway train.
We have never sought development money before now, focusing, rather, on the art and the artists. Everything we've done, we've done with virtually no money: passion, stubbornness, and more than a few would say a bit of insanity have been the driving forces behind our accomplishments.
This, I believe without doubt, is what has made P1xels the pre-eminent iphonic art site in the world. But fear not: money will not spoil P1xels; P1xels has been its own crucible for us as well. We know where we are going.
Almost three years down the road, I still believe iphonic art to be the most vibrant and exciting new art medium on the planet. I ask you to be a part of it. It is still a young art form. Many fine artists have emerged; none are household names. Yet. It remains our mission to continue bringing forth and promoting these pioneering artists and their work.
Please join us.
Thank you.
